reviewText:
I logged 640 hours into a 6 hour game. I really enjoy the atmosphere and the involvement and tools available for co-operative play.

However, if you're playing this game with the mentality of it being a sequal to some of the original Resident Evils, you're going to be disappointed. You will get the most enjoyment out of the game if you go in with the mindset that it will be a cinematic action game.


Edit: Since this is actually getting attention or something, I'm going to emphasize: If you've played any classic Resident Evil games (1, 2, 3), from Resident Evil 4 and onward they are *not the same kind of game*.
While Resident Evil 4 could possibly get a bit of a pass on still being a horror game, this is NOT a horror game. It's an action game. Go into it expecting a co-op-heavy action game, and only then will the game become very enjoyable.

reviewText:
In the light of 0% of people finding my initial review helpful, I've elected to explain a bit more.  This is one of my favourite games of all time.  But this port is disgusting.  The list of intended features pales in comparison to the console versions, because they think they can get away with it.  The DLC comes out 6 years after the game, at a horriffic price, and I buy the game at that time, expecting to repeat my console experience with my girlfriend.  Turns out, not only have they done that, they've removed local co-op entirely.  They've even gone to extra length to prevent modders from adding it.

Even more disgusting is that was a top priority.  Hundreds of people in Capcom's own crash/bug thread on Steam alone, can't even start this bloody thing.  Other people get to certain chapters and can't finish.  Versus is an advertised feature that just doesn't work.  We have region lock and crashes and immense lag.  We are waiting months for a patch and from what I hear none's coming.  What does this say to us?  It says consumers take up the role of playtesting, and if it's worth Capcom's while they'll fix our problems.  What problems have they fixed?  Quite a few, but before any patch of any kind, when converting from GFWL to Steam, the split-screen code modders had used, was totally purged, meaning forcing people to buy extra copies was more important than each customer's gameplay experience.  And of course, as I've said, they've not approached fixing every problem.

Guess what I've done.  Borrowed my friend's PS3 and that copy of the game to play it with my girlfriend.  Because we're not building a bloody gaming PC just for one game.  Let alone one that we may not even be capable of finishing because its publisher have abandoned it.

Now may I say it?

F V C K
Y O U
C A P C O M .

reviewText:
This is still, to this day, the best co-op experience I've ever had in a complete game. Over 1,000 hours on the 360 version, and somewhere close to that between Steam, GFWL, and retail PC disc versions of this game, I'm still enjoying every minute this game is running on any system.

But the important thing to add here is that finally, after about 5 years, the long-awaited Gold Edition content has made its way to PC (and GFWL has been replaced with Steamworks integration). Lost in Nightmares, Desperate Escape, Mercenaries Reunion, Versus, and most importantly, Warrior Chris / Heavy Metal Chris, all in 60fps here on the PC version.

A giant majority of my total hours spent in this game have been in the extra game mode, Mercenaries and Mercenaries Reunion; this is a unique time attack mode where you aim to kill a set number of enemies, breaking time bonuses and getting melee kills for additional time as you progress to complete the stage. With 18 characters / costumes across both Mercenaries and Mercenaries Reunion, as well as three variations of each of the 8 stages (Merc, Reunion, and No Mercy), there is plenty of content to keep you playing and having a good time, single player. But throw that all in with the option to play Duo for these modes (as well as the game's feature co-op campaign), and you've added hundreds of hours of additional gameplay with a co-op partner.

Lost in Nightmares, one of the Gold Edition campaigns which takes place in the flashback sequence where Chris loses his partner Jill Valentine, is one of the many highlights of the game. Like a love letter to their fans, Lost in Nightmares includes a handful of throwbacks and references to old-school Resident Evil flare (cranks, traps, a piano, and an easter egg featuring classic fixed-camera angles for the beginning segment of the campaign, to name a few). It makes me hopeful for the future of the Resident Evil franchise, and it's the most enjoyable add-on content I've ever played.

I have nothing bad to say about this game, and endless good things to say. Since its release in 2009, I've been in love with Resident Evil 5, and I don't think the love for this game will ever die.

reviewText:
Resident Evil 5 is a shooter developed and published by CAPCOM.

Resident Evil 5 takes place in Africa and you play as Chris Redfield and after you finished the campaign once, you can play as Chris partner, Sheva. The environment are African but somewhat worse because there are zombies there. Resident Evil 5 is not as scary as it should but fun nevertheles.

Resident Evil 5 gameplay aren't that exciting for PC but if you played the franchise before, Resident Evil 5 is quite great. One of the downside is the inventory system, it's very limited and makes you have to attend to it everytime. The AI are not bad but not good either. The AI partner can be told to be in assault stance or cover stance. Assault stance makes the AI partner use the best weapons in his/her inventory and explore around on their own, they even open up some barrels and take the items inside them which is quite helpful when you're lazy to do that, but the AI also somewhat stupid when it comes to healing. They tend to waste herbs and medkits on you even when you didn't really need it. reviewText:
The same Resi 5 that you've known for 6 years, now with a litany of new issues after migrating to Steamworks.
Stay away until it gets a patch- this game is BUSTED right now.

A few examples:
Highest-level AA (C16XQ) doesn't function at all
Random crashes to desktop (ex. during the cutscene after a boss fight)
Can't exchange weapons with partner in single-player
Mismatched button prompts in menus (Keyboard prompts when using a controller)
Objects missing from the game world (flowers at the start of 5-1)
Misaligned lens flares
No stages or characters unlocking in Mercenaries, despite repeated A-ranks
Aiming your gun using the Lost in Nightmares DLC classic camera easter egg is broken for Mouse and Keyboard
No laser sight when using Mouse & Keyboard
Missing the promised migration tool for GFWL saves
Splitscreen co-op mod no longer works, no official implementation
Road Warrior Chris and Business Sheva (originally PC-exclusive costumes) have been locked away behind the Gold Edition DLC
Gold Edition DLC is way too expensive. For 90% of the cost of the main game, you get two story chapters, some costumes, a mercenaries variant and some online vs modes that will die out very quickly. This content is 5 years old, but is being treated like a brand-new release from a price standpoint.
At the time of writing (roughly a week and a half after release), Capcom has yet to respond to the enormous number of bug reports in the community forum. Considering that the RE1 remaster still hasn't seen a patch for its framerate issues in the 2.5 months it's been out, you should be very wary of this.
I can't stress this enough- don't give up your hard-earned cash until the game is in a release-worthy state.

EDIT: As of April 10th, Capcom has responded to the community's call for local co-op and 3D support by making the original GFWL version available through Steam's branch system.

Not only is this an incredibly lazy solution, it also doesn't work for any of the Steamworks-only Gold Edition content. It would be a nice hold-over if the development team were working on official implementations of the missing features, but the official steam community forum thread makes no mention of such things.

To me, this indicates that the 'Fix Co-Op' and 'Fix 3D' boxes on Capcom's to-do list have been checked, and that they are moving on. Don't buy this if you're looking for a port that treats the PC platform with respect- you won't find it here.

reviewText:
I never really played any of the RE games. I heard, of course, about the franchise but that is mainly attributed to the films with the Ukrainian model Milla Jovovich. I bought this one on Steam sale many years ago but only recently have I been able to find someone to complete the game with.

And this is an important part to mention: the game is playable with somebody else as there are two protagonists. In case you do not find any one the A.I. can take control of the 2nd player but does a horrible job. So, grab a friend and make sure you also have a Live account as this is the 2nd annoying thing in this game - it still uses an already obsolete service. Once you start a game only via Live can you send the invite and of course the achievements are logged there.

Now that we have settled these two things we can move on to the actual game itself. The story and the cutscenes are VERY cheesy, however, the cutscenes pack a punch! There are more than 50 videos that are all replayable from the main menu. They are awesome! Cheesy but very-well made! There are 6 chapters divided up further into a couple of stages; you easily spend roughly 15 hours with the first playthrough.

The game itself is difficult at times: the gameplay itself is a bit redundant" as no dodging is possible and when aiming your character cannot move
date: at all. You rely on each other and there are certain stages where you have to cooperate closely - only one of you can move while the other must provide protection. Also
recommended: bullets are limited so you have to carefully make every shot as each bullet counts.\n\nAre you annoyed by quick time events? Well
hoursPlayed: RE 5 has many of those. During the cutscenes and also during boss battles. Some combinations popping up require some getting used to and these should be hit hardly very quickly.\n\nOnce you have familiarised yourself with the RE characteristics the game can be enjoyed
voteText: quite much. In fact
helpfulPercent: there are many collectibles and as weapons upgrades can be purchased with the collected treasure all upgraded weapons can be transferred to a 2nd gameplay. Just make sure you pick the New Game + option from the main menu. New difficulty is also unlocked if you want more challenge.\n\nI liked this game. Not really my favourite franchise and will not necessarily go and pick the rest but in case you want to try something new this is easily a good game to pick. To bad it is still 20 bucks considering it is a 5-year old game."

reviewText:
This is the best port of a game since Resident Evil 4. It's also on the same way length as the original retail GFWL version because none of the old glitches were fixed.

There were obviously many things they could've tried working on, the lag glitches in co-op (shooting an enemy takes no effect for a good three seconds, in mercs that can be a massive problem), the fact versus has many crash problems, likewise with merceneries (and reunion), the save file tool not being avalible is also a really bad thing to do if you're releasing a game that has been around for this long. I've dedicated hours to replaying chapters and trying to work through stuff I've had done for years. It's annoying.

We've waited so long for this DLC, but I could've waited a bit longer for a game that worked and wasn't repackaged cola.

If you ever played the original retail GFWL Mercs, you probably know what I'm talking about; the amount of people running around with trainers, cheats and the amazing fact you can glitch having more than two people in a session. However I'd rather be in a game with four Midnight Weskers trying to figure out who I was meant to be teamed up with than this. We were all the same Wesker, someone died during the game and of course it was a terrible session, but it was playable. So far I've spent close to an hour trying to sort out a Versus game that never ended up happening and Mercs games that drop for no reason.

By all means, it's great finally having the full DLC, I've been a longtime fan of Resident Evil despite the usual bad treatment you get as a PC gamer. It's nice finally getting to go through the full stories, but that doesn't exclude the negative, gaping problems they just overlooked with this release.

column17: and so on. They've attained mastery of mechanics as far as I'm concerned. With this knowledge

column19: I know that they have no business making a game in any other genre (except for maybe a turn-based RPG).\n\nBut what is mechanics? Everyone has their own definition
column20: but I look at it as the player's relationship with the world. This covers every action
column21: no matter how subtle. This can be everything from the height and arc of Mario's jump
column22: to what happens when a flying axe is shot
column23: or how much space is necessary for a mayor to dodge a punch. Great mechanics work when you never notice them. It's supposed to be seamless
column24: so when you dodge a thousand bullets in a 2D shooter
column25: you feel like you've been doing it since birth.\n\nThe most prominent aspect of these great mechanics is in how the weapons feel. Each gun has its own characteristics
column26: and using them properly is exciting and rewarding. Majini also respond appropriately depending on where you shoot them and what they're doing. This goes beyond shooting them in the head or in the knees to setup a melee attack. There's other tricks like clipping a shoulder
column27: which causes their arm to fly back. This can be useful if an enemy is carrying dynamite
column28: and it's just out of the player's sights.\n\nIt also can't be stressed enough how effective unrealistic or overly "gamey" mechanics can be. When you're surrounded by monsters in any other game
column29: your first instinct isn't to punch the one that's staggering. In RE5 however
column30: that maneuver can buy you precious invulnerability. All too often
column31: videogames give you these cool techniques you can perform
column32: but they leave you open to attack
column33: so they're never used. Providing an incentive is key
column35: makes them more willing to take risks
column36: and thus have more fun. In the interest of balance
column37: not every game should function in this manner
column38: but it suits the later RE games extremely well.\n\nIn keeping with the arcade game theme
column39: RE5 is best-described as a compatibility shooter. Cooperative? That's the term I'd use to describe Borderlands or something. Sometime in the late 90s/ early 00s
column40: Arcade light-gun developers like Sega & Namco started pushing the compatibility aspect. When you played a light-gun shooter like Let's Go! Jungle or Deadstorm Pirates
column41: end-of-level ratings weren't given just to you. When you played with a friend
column44: it was the relationship that was rated. This meant that if you were doing stuff like hogging all of the enemies or allowing your partner to take damage
column45: you and your partner would get punished with a lower rating. In a way
column46: two people that performed admirably in a light-gun game could be considered lifetime best-friends
column48: etc.\n\nRE5 is designed along those same lines
column49: that's what makes it a compatibility shooter. The next time you play RE5
column50: keep an eye on your partner. Sure there are plenty of moments that force the co-op angle
column52: or those times where you have to cover your partner while they do something
column53: but I'm talking about all of the subtle aspects. For example
column54: note the laser-sights. This isn't just a holdover from RE4. You can see where your partner is aiming
column55: so you know when to cover their back. Enemies tend to come from multiple directions
column56: so situations where you do the lion's share of the work are few and far between. Over time you develop a sense of what your partner is thinking. You know when they have a situation handled
column57: or when they need to be bailed out.\n\nThere's also the context-sensitive B button. When you give someone a herb
column58: pressing the B button will say "Thank you"
column59: and you'll hear some variant of "Nice!" when your partner nails a sweet headshot. Typically
column60: when you perform some action in spectacular fashion
column61: you'll see "Great!" pop up on-screen or hear it spoken (My personal favorite is "Nice Driving" in Daytona USA. This is a holdover from the arcade days. Arcade games are short
column62: and your actions have immediate consequences. When you do something right
column63: the game pats you on the head. RE5 is designed so that you and your partner are expected to pat each other on the head
column64: thus we have the B button.\n\nRE5's campaign is altogether solid
column65: but it has some definite mis-steps. Boss-fights in RE games tend to be generally hit or miss. More often than not they're about taking advantage of clumsy AI path-finding or shooting large glowing targets with the magnum. RE5 has all this
column66: and a bullet-sponge turret boss to boot. There's also the 5-2 boss
column67: which screams "Use a rocket launcher on me". Also
column68: while not-zombies with guns aren't a huge deal to me
column69: they're a massive pain in Professional mode. This
column70: combined with the ridiculous short revival time (you have to be right on top of your partner to save them)
column71:
is just annoying. For the most part though I think RE5 is solidly put-together. It pushes the compatibility elements quite well.

Mercenaries is absolutely perfect. There's no need for a wall of text to explain why.

Altogether
column72: RE5 is a very satisfying game. Give it another go if you haven't already."

reviewText:
The Steamworks version of this game was heavily advertised as being free of the GFWL trashware - that's why I bought it. It turns out the most recent patch reintroduced and mandated the use of Games for Windows Live, effectively nullifying my purchase.

The game also crashes if you don't have GFWL installed, or in my case, under any circumstances. It functioned just fine before the latest patch. The developers have basically abandoned the forum at this point, so if all of the proposed community solutions don't work for you, you're out of luck.

If you enjoy archaic DRM systems and/or games that crash at launch, you'll love Resident Evil 5.

reviewText:
The gameplay features a fun score attack mode based on killing enemies quickly enough before time runs out, and killing them in specific ways to gain extra time.

As a bonus, you get to experience a comedic interactive story with Josh telling about his adventures at the docks, Chris punching a boulder, and Wesker monologuing about wheat.

After 5 years, Capcom has actually finally ported over the Gold Edition content to PC alongside the Steamworks transition. Which is very great news, unfortunately it also means the game is now in an extremely buggy state thanks to the Steamworks transition. Hopefully it's something Capcom will patch and fix.

reviewText:
I'm a RE fan, sometimes despite myself. The games aren't scary, but they are enjoyable. RE4 was, perhaps, the high mark of Capcom's decision to go in an action-oriented direction. The gameplay was fresh, the story was enjoyable, and the setting they chose was remarkably well done. I'll go so far as to say that they hit the 'rural horror where something is terribly wrong with the locals' vibe better than most proper horror titles do.

RE5 came fast on the heels of 4, and basically has the same kind of gameplay with a reduced emphasis on exploring the environment and a focus on violence. The choice to move to Africa for the setting wasn't a bad one - colonial issues aside, there's plenty of things to be scared of out there. It provides a great excuse to combine dilapidated equipment and urban environments with a vast selection of rural locales. Nothing wrong with that at all.

The Good:
Chris and Sheva are both fairly fun to play, with a handful of distinct weapons to each one. They also have distinct combat styles, with Chris being a 'roid-pumped bruiser and Sheva being more of a finesse fighter. The enemies are more dangerous than RE4 - the humanoid enemies are better armed, and the non-human ones are tougher than their counterparts in RE4. There are new ones running around which are almost too tough (those damned mantis-ants, for instance), but you'll find a decent challenge throughout.
There's a large supply of weapon and costume unlocks as well. The costumes are a bit of a wash (the club gear ones are especially terrible), but the weapons are solid. The minigun in particular is great to play with - it chews enemies to pieces, but you'll need time to let it rev up.

The Bad:
The inventory system is crap. There's no other way to describe it. The elegant attache case from RE4 was far better, but they swapped it out for a more traditional limited slot system. You'll find yourself swapping ammo and the like with your partner more often then you should need to.
The partner AI is...okay, for the most part. Okay, but not great. They'll still waste healing items on you when you don't need them, and they do tend to get mauled if you leave them off by themselves.
Wesker, your main opponent, has crossed over into Mary Sue territory by this point. He's your typical modern body horror anime villain cranked up to 11, bouncing RPGs and heavy caliber weapons like he was half Kryptonian. It's only his over-the-top voice acting and performance that saves him as a villain.
And, of course...the race issues. Really, this isn't too bad for the first and later acts of the game. Most of your enemies are a variety of ethnic types, not out of line for the right parts of Africa. In the late stages, the Manjini you're facing are in advanced stages of infection, so most of those are a necrotic blue with obvious decay creeping in around the edges. Again, not a problem.
The middle acts of the game, which take place in a tribal reserve and underground city...there's the problem locale. You're up against tribesmen who wouldn't be out of place in a mid-quality pulp novel, attacking you with spears. The game tries to hand wave this by stating the locals went crazy, and reverted to the 'old ways', but it's a bit crass and kind of silly at best. I don't think there was an intentional bid to be offensive, this is pulp story/action-adventure cliche territory, but it's definitely not a comfortable thing and I don't fault people who find it offensive.

Would I recommend?
Absolutely. This is a fun game, and issues aside you'll have a good time shooting monsters and running for your life when you're not shooting monsters. The voice acting is cheesy, the story is pulp silliness, the setting is great, and the action delivers more often than it stumbles. If the second act of the game doesn't put you off, you'll have a blast.

reviewText:
To be honest, it was first RE game, I have played since PSX.

Because it has been created for the console, I didn't like the way, how to control the character on PC. Even when I tried to play it with an Xbox controller. This was one of two reasons, why I gave up on this game like three times before I finished it completely. Most of the things were very different to other shooting games like being not able to move while shooting or reloading. Also accessing the inventory, because I am not able to memorize what gun i set up for positions above 4..

But as I remember all the RE PSX games I've used to play - the story is touching your heart. You wanna be the hero and having sexy Sheva as your partner is flooding your veins with an adrenaline. The surrounding graphics are not perfect, but thanks to that, the whole game runs smoothly as butter.

Pros:
Good storyline
Sexy Sheva
Bonuses (Cut scenes, costumes, figurines, unlocking game modes)
Smooth runs
I found just 2 small bugs by myself (and those were no big deals) - BRAVO!
Easy ways to find ammo
Good map navigation

Cons:
The way of controlling the characters
Some bosses were really tough and you have to repeat the fight one hundred million times..
You're not able to chat with your online partner and the commands are very limited
Problems with Windows Live Account at the beginning of game
If someone wants to join you, it's not possible immediately. You have to restart the game from a checkpoint..

The cons are really not so terrible I couldn't recommend the game. And I will surely play it yet for few hours!

reviewText: The latest in the Resident Evil series. It's a pretty cool game you play as Chris Redfield who now has shoulders bigger than his head as you punch solid boulders and shout words of encouragement to save the day, the second player also plays as some not so black woman who shifts between African and English accents faster than I can actually change weapons with the somewhat awkward inventory screen. The game has ditched its horror roots in favor of punching people in the ♥♥♥♥ing head and making said head explode! Your main foes in this latest adventure are Quasimodo, a Batorpion, an incredibly large man with a beard, an annoying woman named after Microsoft excel and an incredibly British dude who think's he is part of the matrix series of films...The game is somewhat short and is much better played with two players as you can really just laugh about all the absurd things going on. Overall though the game is a blast, even if you can't move and shoot. Pure high octane action at it's best.

reviewText:
Chris Redfield and Sheva Alomar are investigating possible bioterrorism threats in Africa: as it befits the series these threats become real soon enough and their investigation'll turn into a fight for survival against infected locals and B.O.W.s.
Resident Evil 5 follows in the footsteps of its predecessor with an even more action-packed combat and fully fledged partner system: while those looking for a true survival horror will likely be disappointed the game is an excellent, if different, entry in the series.

PROS:

-overall graphics and character/ enemy models and animations make this a good looking game

-nice soundtrack and sound design

-a pretty interesting and serious story with a few twists, gone is also most of the cheesy dialogue

-the action oriented combat is very enjoyable and fairly challenging

-boss fights are tough and tense affairs

-a considerable amount of weapons to find/ buy and upgrade

-good level variety

-story mode is quite lengthy, taking 12 to 15 hours to beat

NEUTRAL:

-controls can feel a bit clunky at times, nothing too bad but some sections requiring quick movements/ fine aim might feel harder than they'd be due to it: cover system is very awkward

-there's still a few QTE cutscenes and, while I personally don't enjoy them, they're at least way easier than the RE4 ones

-inventory management can still feel fiddly at times due to the limited spaces

CONS:

-the whole having a partner" thing and the game being designed with co-op in mind can make single-player a bit annoying at times especially on boss fights

-gone are most of the atmosphere and survival horror elements

-a chapter (including its boss fight) is basically a lengthy turret section
date:
it honestly was annoying to play and felt out of place

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=659238683

As said RE 5 leaves most of its survival horror roots behind in favor of fast-paced combat against a plethora of enemies: it's different but it works well and things can get pretty tense when you're facing a crowd of infected or a particularly strong foe/ boss. The story is also quite deep
recommended: interesting and tied to previous entries of the series: the fact most of the cheesy lines are gone is also something I truly appreciate. You'll meet both new and returning enemy types while exploring varied levels such as shanty towns
voteText: caves etc... this not only keeps things fresh but also requires you to change your tactics whenever a new foe comes up.\n\nThe co-op oriented game design is a mixed bag
helpfulPercent: while heaps of fun if played with someone the single player suffers from it at times. Sheva's AI is a very good shot but her reactions aren't always sensible and she'll sometimes waste ammo
votesHelpful:
not follow you fast enough or generally make a nuisance of herself: this isn't too bad overall but I can only imagine how terrible it'd get on the higher difficulty levels. Bosses can also become harder than they'd be if you're playing with an AI companion as they might find it hard to maneuver accordingly or use their weapons at their best.

Despite a few gripes with the AI and the co-op design Resident Evil 5 is an absolutely fun and rewarding game even if played alone: I'd say it's a recommended purchase for fans of the series/ genre as long as you're not put off by the change in pace and the lack of survival horror elements.

reviewText:
Gave Sheeva a Shotgun with ammo and two Incendiary Grenades.

Sheeva shot her Pistol until it was empty and then screamed for help.

Sheeva got attacked by The Walking Ebola.

10.5/10 - Would let Sheeva die again.
____

In all seriousness, this is when the series cemented it's interest in pursuing action set peices instead of dreadful horror set peices. They did this by giving you more outside settings during daylight and introducing a new enemy type: The J'avo. Unlike the Zombie, the J'avo is fast, resistant and can even operate weaponry - giving a whole new sort of tension to the gameplay.

It kind of divided the fans a bit. All of this said, this is by no means a bad game at all. It's still got an engaging, ridiculous, over-the-top story with everyone you love and grotesque monster's to eat your flesh... but you're such a total badass by 1.5/4 into the story that I recommend playing on the highest difficulty.

Online co-op functionality, no offline.

New game plus upon completion - you carry over your inventory to be even more of a badass.

Mercenaries available as an extra game mode.

I highly recommend it as a fan of the series.

reviewText:
Люди настолько алчны , что пытаются убить друг друга за гроши , терзают друг друга в клочи ради своего же блага.Но забывают о других людях которые не хотели причинять боль... Но они были вынуждены...
Среди останках прошлого находились и люди с добрым сердцем но их было мало...Истерзанные в душе звери требующие только убивать.Вырывались наружу но...Они не смогли удержать зверя.
Сколько людей погибло напрасно , бес толку , скольких друзей товарищей мы готовы потерять ... Сколько?
Видимо достаточно.Люди с давних пор убивали как не кто другой.Человек единственный зверь на земле, не один зверь не один монстр не сравнится с ним.

Сама игра прекрасна...Не разу не видела что-бы выживание с одними зомбями в будке было-бы так интересно, игра нам поясняет события происходящим через 4 года после RE 4 части, образцы вируса каким-то образом попали на черный рынок и теперь угроза заражения снова актуальна. Наученные прошлым опытом, спецслужбы создают организацию B.S.A.A., которая будет сосредоточенна на борьбе с новыми биологическими террористами.


Управление в Resident Evil 5 стало намного приятней, если на геймпаде всё итак было хорошо, то теперь и для ПКашников наступил праздник! Отныне не обязательно покупать джойстик, чтобы насладиться этой замечательной игрой, а управление на клаве и мышке нечем не уступает джойстику. Теперь не нужно ставить моды и прочий софт, чтобы спокойно поиграть на полюбившемся устройстве.

Персонажи харизмотичны и интересны. То главный злодей Вескер то наша бывшая соратница Джилл которая была подчинённая не по своей воле , Крис со своим ужасным прошлым. Все персоонажи занкомы из прошлых частей , поэтому я чувствовала себя в своей тарелке

Мне игра очень понравилась , много интересных миссий , интересное управления , монстры из фильма Обитель зла" который является прямым наследником игры

reviewText:
Resident Evil 5 is more about action and getting awesome weapons than about horror. The game is nice if you like action games. Old RE fans will be disappointed though. There is no safe room in this game nor typewriter but a lot of useless minigames and features like unlimited ammo...

This game is focused on co-op mode. You can play alone with a dumb bot and get frustrated or play together with a friend :) There aren't any classic zombies in this game, only infected people who are armed to the teeth :P The story is kinda boring and bland. You might have already figure out the whole plot once you see all the important characters.

This game has a lot of issues at the beginning and there are still some bugs left which Capcom may never will fix. Luckily we have a great community here which created some patches and fixes for those issues. (no more region lock for example)

Mercenaries/ReunionMercenaries is a gamemode that unlocks when you finished the game. You can choose a character and play on different recycled maps. (except the last) The goal is to make a lot of combos while killing the infected to get a good score until the timer expires. Having a good rank will unlock new characters.

Reunion is the same gamemode as Mercenaries but with some new DLC characters which is not included in the full version.

Untold Story DLCIf you want all the achievements you have to buy this DLC (yet another bait to milk of your money) There are some bonus features & campaigns which are included in the untold story DLC. One of the campaign called Lost in Nightmare" is pretty good imo. It is focused more on the horror aspect and manage to entertain me through the end. The only downside is the short playtime :(

Versus mode is one of the main feature in this DLC but sadly it is dead since no one play this mode anymore. (Also good luck at finding people to complete those achievements... I don't care anymore :P) The DLC is almost worthless without the "Lost in Nightmare" campaign. Buy it at your own risk!

ConclusionIf you like action and smart zombies then this is the game for you!
All the other ones should buy it only on sales."

reviewText: Resident Evil 5 is a fun co-op horror shooter. Unlike the classic Resident Evil games, this game is more focused on action and cooperation with either the AI partner or another player. Personally, I think that the modern RE games don't quite hold up to the classic ones, but that dosen't mean that this is a bad game. No, Resident Evil 5 is a great game. The gameplay is solid: It's a fairly slow paced shooter, with the from RE4 (or more like RE: Dead Aim) typical run, stand and shoot mechanic. There are tons of licensed guns in the game (I'm looking at you RE4 and 6) and they have great detail for a third person shooter. From a graphical standpoint, this game is still a sight for sore eyes. It got better graphics than RE6, which suffers from several low-res textures and low-poly mesh at many points. Movement is pretty basic in RE5, you can walk slowly, run and use a quick turn key. There's no jumping around, rolling or sprinting in this game, and in my opinion, that's a good thing. In RE6 these features seemed partially unnecessary and felt like they came straight out of a some Asian Kung Fu movie.\nThe melee system has been slightly expanded compared to it's predecessor, you can now execute different melee moves depending on the enemy's body part you hit and the resulting stun animation. Every character has his own unique melee moves. You can also chain combos with your partner, the last melee attack of the combo will result in a very powerful attack like Chris' Haymaker or Wesker's Ghost Butterfly. The co-op mechanics are decent, although I feel like the game would have benefited from being a single player experience like RE4. It just makes it much easier for the player to dive into the game's world if you are alone, without a partner spamming Hurry!"

reviewText:
This game suffered quite heavily from previous-game-being-really-good-and-this-game-not-being-as-good-itis, so sadly I expect I will be a bit too harsh in this review. I can live with that.

Resident Evil 4 realised that the whole concept of the series was quite ludicrous, and went very over-the-top and was very obviously not taking itself that seriously. This game goes back and takes itself all too seriously again. Boo. The story is just too damn serious, and doesn't have any fun. Also it doesn't make much sense. But then the stories in Resi games have never been great, so I suppose that's not really a surprise.

The gameplay of this game was not particularly exciting, and certainly not very different to Resi 4 (but far better than that shocking Resi 4 PC port - play that on gamecube instead, or at least fix the PC version with mods). It looks perfectly fine and some of the puzzles are actually well done. There are far too many annoying quicktime bits though. Also parts of the final boss fight are absolutely stupid in co-op (whoever gets Sheva, I'm sorry you will be in so much pain due to that terrible button mash).

Far from great, but not terrible either. Kinda meh. If you're a big fan of the Resi series I guess this would be worth playing, but otherwise give this one a miss.

reviewText: Resident Evil 5, is actually the Seventh game in the Resident Evil series and was released in 2010. Resident Evil 5 is a Third-Person shooter/Horror game where you play once again as Chris Redfield, formerly of The original Resident Evil, Resident Evil Code Veronica and The Umbrella Chronicles, who partners with a woman named Sheva Alomar, which can be co-op played online or locally via split screen. The game takes place 5 years after the events of Resident Evil 4, with Chris Redfield no longer being a member of the STARS, Special Tactics and Rescue Service. Chris is now a member of the BSAA, Bioterrorism Security Assessment Alliance, who is on a mission to stop the sale of the progenitor bioweapon, which is a combination of the original T and G viruses.\n\nWithout giving away any more spoilers, I will say that Resident Evil 5, definitely looks good considering it is 7-years-old this year. Resident Evil 5 also has a survivors mode and a slayers mode, both being competitive multiplayer modes, as well as the traditional single player and Two-player co-op mode. I originally had this game on the PS3 and it was both fun and fantastic as a part of the Resident Evil series.

reviewText:
It's a game best enjoyed in co-op play, but you can still have fun along the AI once you get used to its patterns. The graphics are pretty good for its time, no flaws there. The combat system it's not great but good enough and it's flaws can add to the survival and suspense tone of the game. But to get a good taste of that you need to play in the highest difficulties. The inventory systems is a bit clunky but you can make it work. I think they did a good job between the balance of combat and enemy AI. The mercenaries game mode is fun and challenging, but the DLC stories are too simple. In terms of story... it's not the best of the series but you can still feel the characters and enjoy them, especially if you know about the RE saga. With almost 200 hrs at the present time I can assure you that this game has a lot of replay value. Oh! and the soundtrack is awesome.

Pros:
+ Co-op environment
+ Enemy AI
+ Replay value
+ Combat
+ Extra content
+ Soundtrack

Cons:
- Inventory system
- Ally AI

reviewText: Had a really good time going through this alone and found the babysitting just a tiny bit annoying, not a dealbreaker. Cooping with a friend, like I'm doing now, is where the game shows its best side, though. So consider playing with someone if the single player experience does not agree with you.\n\nThis is classic Resident Evil, with all the bells and whistles you should be used to by now. It promised and delivered excactly what I expected. I feel that I got my moneys' worth and then some, so this one is definitely recommended.

reviewText: Being a big Resident Evil fan, I was surprised I didn't like this more. It's a great game but just didn't feel as much like a Resident Evil game as I was expecting. This game felt really difficult at times even on the easiest difficulty. Probably due to the fact that I suck at it and the computer A.I. certainly doesn't help. The A.I. can be pretty useless at times. Having a friend playing with you would solve that problem, I imagine. But the plot and atmosphere is still pretty good. Overall a solid entry into the Resident Evil series.

reviewText:
TL;DR: Great game, not for hardcore fans of horror series, an action packed bro-op third person shooter, stupid ai controlled partner, cheesy action movie style story, presentation of game is great, gameplay elements in the game really shine. 7.5/10 Enjoyable experience.

Things to note before reading review: I've bought Gold Edition and this was my first ever resident evil game I've played.

This game is exactly as other people say an action face paced third person shooter. Its like a cheesy action movie with scripted explosions, quick time events, and even a car chase. A bro-op action shooter that never stops delivering the action. Did I enjoy it? Hell ya those 70 hours spent on the game were mainly messing around with randoms online and even beating the game on professional. Mercenaries is also a main focus of Resident evil bringing out and showing the fun and varying combat system.

Story: Its a cheesy action packed third person shooter following the footsteps of Chris and Sheva as they travel through Africa on a mission from the BSAA. Fighting against bioterrorism they fight local zombie like creatures and fight things that increase in size, bullet soaking power, and strength. Another virus is back to plague African villages and tribes with some randomly placed journals that tell deeper back stories on certain areas, people, and experiments. There is a lot of depth to the environment that resident evil 5 has laid out but its over shadowed by all those action sequences and over saturation of actions packed missions.

Gameplay: Suberb, Resident evil 5 really takes the cake as a co-op shooter. The only real problem I find in it is the quick time events that are absolutely annoying. You have a inventory system holding 9 possible objects of ammo, weapons, herbs, etc. You can find treasure to sell and use for money to upgrade weapons, buy new ones, and so much more. Shooting also has interesting aspects of being able to shoot enemies in the face, arm, or feet which will trigger 3 different types of melee attacks that you can choose. The depth and ability to perform combos is very interesting especially with a human controlled partner. This game play element is especially useful for mercenaries for comboing and extending time.

They also removed GFWL and added steamworks. I never really knew the problem with GFWL that everybody finds.

In conclusion, a great game in the aspect of game play. Capcom has really done it with this game Hardcore Resident Evil fans that wish the series would go back to its Horror roots will definitely be disappointed with this game. The story doesn't shine with anything interesting or new just overviewing another virus and some predictable plot points. Game play is great through the upgrade system, treasures, and melee attacks. Great to play with friends.

7.5/10
If this game is on sale get it. Highest sale seen by me is 66%

reviewText: The title says it's Resident Evil but it's far from a true survival horror experience. It's an action game. There are no save points, it's checkpoint based. All that is OK as long as your expectations are established. I played through this multiple times on PS3 and enjoyed the co-op aspect and wanted to experience it on PC with friends. Sadly co-op doesn't seem to work. I can't tell whether this is Capcom's fault or Microsoft's poor GFWL solution. There doesn't seem to be any support for this game anymore so neither Steam or Capcom can give me an explanation on why I keep getting Game session canceled" when attempting to play co-op games.\n\nEdit: 3/6/2016: So GFWL is finally gone and replaced with steamworks and the co-op experience is now fully playable. It's hard for me to change my recommendation from NO to YES because of lame the story is
date: but when you're playing the RAID mode or through the campaign with a friend
recommended: it's definitely enjoyable. The game is definitely middle of the road when it comes to grading."

reviewText:
A very strange game.

I'm not sure exactly how Resident Evil went from a survival horror game to a bad imitation of Gears of War, but... it happened.

The game starts off in a good space and actually stays very entertaining for a significant chunk of time, but around the time the zombies start riding motorcycles (?) and you defeat a giant by sitting still on a turret and shooting at his feet (??) the game takes a rather weird turn for the worse. Enemies suddenly become bullet sponges and you spend massive amounts of ammo either locking an enemy in an animation until it dies, or hoping to hit the tiny weak spot that will eventually kill it.

I would not put a vote of confidence for single player, but if you're going to play with a friend through the cooperative mode, you'll probably have a good time and share a mutual feeling of What the hell is going on?" when you realize you're playing a really crappy cover shooter instead of a Resident Evil game.

I mean

reviewText: Like RE4 its not survival horror but in my opinion is better as it utilises the type of co-op action to create a very enjoyable experience. The story is very interesting with fun bosses and various enemies, has lots of replay value with different difficulties, collectibles, upgrades and of course achievements. The extra mode mercenaries lets you play alone or with a partner to survive and defeat as many enemies as possible within the time limit (being able to extend it breaking time bonuses) on numerous levels with different characters and costumes which I found addictively fun. Overall RE5 is a great game but I would recommend getting the gold edition to ANYONE who buys this as you will get so much more worth your money including mercenaries reunion (like mercenaries but with different characters and weapons not playable in the original version), Versus- which can be fun with friends but has clunky elements and not the best matchmaking + 2 DLC story modes with fan favourite Jill Valentine- 1 being a homage to RE1 and brings back survival horror while keeping the co-op and modern controls.\nThe ONLY real criticism I have for this game (more so the gold edition steam port than anything) is that there is quite a few bugs- occasionally enemies get stuck in mercenaries meaning you have to find them to kill them, the matchmaking is bad with private slots not functioning properly and automatically region locking who you play with [there is a mod which removes this however] and lobbies not being accurate. If capcom simply fixed these minor bugs this game would be perfect but they haven't addressed this and it's looking as though they won't with the last patch being over a year ago.

reviewText: I grew up watching and playing the Resident Evil games and watching the movies and reading the books, and I have to say, the makers of Biohazard should be ashamed of this. The franchise has turned from a mindful game of puzzles and fun(horror, zombies, grotesque creatures out of a Lovecraftian terror) to a sad below expectations FPS. Resident Evil 4 had its spikes of worthwile gaming, but couldn't hold a candle to the others games, but at least as an FPS it held its own. This sad excuse for a FPS is a sad and downright depressing adventure for anyone who has loved the Biohazard/Resident Evil franchise. There's no finese, no love, no care, no intelligence in this game. They've successfully sucked all the delights that Resident Evil was known for straight out of this game.

reviewText:
This game continues in the vain of Resident Evil 4s second half, which means: MORE ACTION
The first half (roughly 5 to 6 Hours) is pretty nice, not really any horror but on higher difficulty (i played on survival) you get that survival feeling, e.g. scarce ammunition/healing items and enemys do a lot of damage.

That was pretty much the good part.

Capcom decided to ramp up the action and enemy count over the course of the game and it gets worse and worse.
The pacing is awful, there are barely atmospheric downtime sections, they throw wave after wave of enemys at you ALL.THE.TIME.  I just wished for it to be over after some time. They completely drop the ball when introducing zombies with guns which are still surprisingly accurate and do tons of damage.
And all this while keeping the tank controls from RE 4 and an annoying inventory system which is much worse this time around because the game continues in real time while you're in it.

A lot of levelparts and (boss)fights also overstay their welcome and this game would have benefited from some streamlining, content wise. The whole finale just goes on and on and on.
And don't think of playing this with the AI. Sheva is good at saving your butt when you are dying but the amount of failures i got because of her  not moving when she should, not hitting enemys but shooting half her mag in the air or standing in my line of sight.

The game turns from decently fun to a real chore halfway trough, not recommended.
Play RE4 or the HD Remaster from the first game instead.

reviewText: No it's not as good" as RE4 but that should not deter you from playing it. It had a hefty development process dating all the way back to that concept trailer shown back in 2005 and it didn't even release until March 2009. Yes
date: originally it was just Chris but Capcom cashed in on how easy "co-op" appeal is and with the whole racist backlash (That would be 10x worse in 2015
recommended: thanks tumblr) they threw in Sheva. It's still one of the best looking games of last gen even compared to RE6 although that's not much of an achievement when you look at RE6. Good music
hoursPlayed: good atmospheric design - By this I mean it's got a really nice murky urban feeling in the early levels of the game as opposed to being scary
voteText: sure it's daylight but it's Africa what do you expect? Story/Scenario is really stupid though
helpfulPercent: you're following up on things we know nothing about and we never really see most characters outside of cutscenes also for some reason despite being veterans Chris and Jill are both low ranking officers in an organization they started.\n\nPlaying solo is a miserable experience having to babysit the AI and feed it your ammo and use your money to upgrade its weapons if you want it to keep up
votesHelpful: the real experience in the game is the co-op. Having a responsive partner to use the voice commands given in the game adds to the whole co-operative nature of the game. Getting grabbed and being helped out then to quickly press a button to say "Thanks for the help" really makes it more satisfying that you have someone to assist you. The core gameplay itself hasn't changed too much from the series it's essentially "RE4 with co-op" having no typewriters anymore
votesTotal: no merchant what little remained of the core RE series to begin with is the tank controls. The controls themself take some getting used to and having being spoilt by RE6's masterful character control (The only good thing about the game) I had some difficulty playing it a while back but now it's out of my system I can easily manage playing it again.\n\nThe post-game content is serviceable
votesFunny: as you go through the game you're to acquire hidden emblems that unlock content for you with the more you amass. Be they files on all creatures and people in the game
commentsCount: filters for the game itself
column16: small statues that detail the models of the game or even unlockable costumes to which both Sheva and Chris have 2 each of. The game also contains the series staple Mercenaries which started in RE3 and carried over to RE4 and now RE5. The DLC content is also largely worth it having two scenarios that fill in the missing pieces of the story a lot easier granted you even care about it
column17: two more costumes for Chris and Sheva (Well
column18: technically only 1 each on PC since you get the other set you got on consoles PC had already) and a remixed Mercenaries mode featuring two characters from RE5 and two old returning characters from the first game in the series.\n\nWith a fair amount of replay value and the likes or Mercs (provided the community is still alive) it's a game definitely worth your time even with all the flaws present the amount of time put into it is staggering compared to some of Capcom's later efforts."

reviewText: Пятая часть известной серии в игровой индустрии RESIDENT EVIL.К нам вернулся наш главный протагонист с первой части и с Code Veronica-Крис Редфилд.В игре нам предстоит побыть в Африке,так как было обнаружено там нечто странное и судя по всему новая атака биотеррористов) Но наш протагонист будет не один,а вместе передвигаться с новым персоной в игровой серии-Шивой.Игра мне понравилась в целом,но однако не чувствуется ужаса,как испытывал в 1,2,3 и 4.И без зомбей непривычно (4 часть как раз уже без зомбей) Но я не жалуюсь.В плане атмосферности,сюжета,хардкорности и геимплея-игра хороша.Помню как приходилось выживать толком без патронов и страдал часто от их нехватки) Только если играть одному с ботом,бот  уж сильно потупивает бывает.Но в целом,как говорил игра качественная и хорошая.Моя оценка-9,2/10.

reviewText: I'll start of by saying that Resident Evil 5 is a fantastic game to play with or without a partner. And now that it has made it's way to Steamworks, it deserves to be re-played. Of all the games I've played from the franchise, this one didn't deliver the horror experience I was looking for. The enemies did not appear particularly frightening, as well as the atmosphere wasn't creepy at all. The item machanism isn't balanced. You would have to decide and discard items in order to obtain more (total of nine slots.) Either increase the capacity of items you can carry in your arsenal, or spawn less items. The new Steamworks version of the game eliminated the support for Directx10. Wheather you have a low or high-end PC, you will be left with Directx9 as your renderer. Despite all that, the game never gets old and is still worth playing over and over again, especially with a partner. As a true Resident Evil fan, I definately recommend this one!

reviewText: It has potential, but has so many basic design flaws. You'd think after four previous versions of the game, they would get things right. Different mouse sensitivities depending on if you are running or walking causes dizziness. The ability to buy guns and not ammo just represents a bad design decision. Interactive cut scenes just cause death while you try to relax in between levels. An obvious console port that is painful to play with a keyboard & mouse; yet the inaccuracy of a game controller for first person shooting frustrates matters even more. The best feature of this game is the co-op mode combined with decent graphics, but frequent disconnects will keep you looking for something else to play.

reviewText:
Fantastic Game. Although this game is called Resident Evil 5, it does not feel like any of the past Resident Evil games. The 'Horror' has been dropped off and replaced with 'Action'. This is a great Action-Shooter, but a bad Resident Evil.

The Good:
-Great Controls (I reccomend a game pad of some discription)
-The weapons feel pretty powerful
-Very good with a partner to play with

The Bad:
-There is really no Horror element
-A.I. partner is really bad (Seriously don't play this without someone else)
-Some action serquences are way too long.

All in all, this game is pretty good.
8/10 With a friend.
7/10 Without a friend.

reviewText:
I might get some hate from this, but this is my favorite Resident Evil game.  It's not scary, it's not like the old school games for ps1, and it happens mostly during the day.  But this is still the best of the series.  Get this game for:

Great Co op play
Fun, over the top, RE storyline minus some of the scares
Rediculous replayability with multiple difficulties and mercinaries mode
Graphics that still look decent today
Upgrades, upgrades, upgrades.

I've played this game for at least a hundred hours on 360, but it's still fun for me to play.  If you want to play the same Resident Evil as 4 then GO PLAY 4.  Does everyone really want Capcom to keep the series exactly the same? That would be pretty boring.

reviewText:
Evolution is a critical part in the existance of the world. As time goes by circumstances change and species either adapt or go extinct. Resident Evil 5 is all about evolution, both in content and in gameplay. It might not be what you want it be, but it works.

Resident Evil 5 is branded as the black sheep of the Resident Evil franchise. It is the installment where everything went overboard and everything that made Resident Evil, Resident Evil was replaced with elements that made it Gears of War. Resident Evil 5 is a third person shooter at heart and not a survival horror game. This polarised many fans of the series. Even at its darkest, Resident Evil 5 isn't scary. Unsettling at best, but you're so stacked on ammo and firepower at all times that you'll be hard pressed to actually fear for your life. So, in short, you'll be gunning your way through posessed villagers, various monsters and a broad assortment of bosses; and it is very enjoyable to do so.

The game drops you, Chris Redfield, Resident Evil 1 allumni, and Sheva Alomar, series newcomer and dark horse, in Africa where you're tasked to apprehend an arms dealer. Things quickly escalate when bio-weapons are involved and they're stronger and more advanced than anything seen before. The story proceeds to wrap up the ends brought forth in the earlier installments and pits you against an old enemy whose voice is arguably the sexiest baritone ever to grace the airwaves. The presentation and pace help sell the completely insane plot. If you're not an initated follower of Resident Evil  then you'll be dumbfounded. However, if you're in on the mania, than be prepared for a turbulent and explosive ride.

Gameplay is fast and agressive. The combat system actively encourages to get your hands dirty. And since you're accompanied by an AI partner, or possible coop player, you'll be dishing out pain left and right. The AI's aim is to be commended. While their inventory management leaves something to be desired, the computer player knows when to shoot and it makes it count. It helps you get past some of the more frustrating moments that much easier, allowing you to get back to work asap. And you'll be doing work. The shooting from Resident Evil 4 is back, but the enemies are more resiliant and they want your fist in their face. Chris' enormous biceps are going to show their worth when you get the hang of it.

Resident Evil 5 is a violent and agressive evolution of the game that Resident Evil 4 was. It isn't as revolutionary and some parts are bound to rub you the wrong way, but it is fun game to play. The viceral violence, the story and level design all add up to something really cool. Add to that some of the best action set pieces ever since they became a thing and you have a recipe for success.

reviewText: Resident Evil 5 is a fun and frantic evolution of RE4's breakthrough gameplay and the series' horror themes.\n\nThirteen years ago, Capcom helped revolutionize the action adventure world with Resident Evil, a game that would define an entirely new genre dubbed survival horror." In the years that followed
date: the series continued to build upon the standards set by the first game
voteText: Resident Evil 4 radically departed from its predecessors and broke new ground as a more action-oriented game. Resident Evil 5
helpfulPercent: the latest offering in the long-running series
votesHelpful: expands on the action-heavy formula of its forerunner and is built from the ground up to support cooperative gameplay. Though it can no longer be considered a survival horror game
votesTotal: Resident Evil 5 manages to retain and effectively translate the most important aspect of that genre--tension--into its new mechanics. It crafts a fun
votesFunny:
collaborative experience that will keep you on your toes the entire time.

Having two agents in the field lets you team them up to trade weapons or push dumpsters.
Ten years after the destruction of Raccoon City
commentsCount: former S.T.A.R.S. Alpha team member Chris Redfield is an agent of the B.S.A.A. This paramilitary anti-bio-organic weapons organization travels the globe to seek out and destroy Umbrella Corporation's creations
column16: which have fallen into the hands of terrorists following the collapse of the multinational pharmaceutical company. When Chris gets a tip that a known weapons dealer will be making a big deal in the remote African nation of Kijuju
column17: he heads there to put a stop to it and learn what he can about the mysterious doomsday project known only as Uroboros. Chris is joined by Sheva Alomar
column19: and together they battle wave after wave of infected villagers
column20: horribly mutated monsters
column21: and even series archnemesis
column22: Albert Wesker.\n\nThe core combat mechanics haven't fundamentally changed since Resident Evil 4. The action still unfolds from an over-the-shoulder perspective
column23: certain battles or cutscenes are accompanied by brief quick-time events
column24: and you still have to stop moving to fire your weapon (though you gain a bit more mobility thanks to your newfound ability to walk sideways). Resident Evil 5's slow movement and gunplay take some time to get used to
column25: and folks expecting a run-and-gun game may find the action too sluggish for their tastes. Fortunately
column26: this slowness isn't really an issue within the game
column27: because enemies are deliberate with their attacks and are better handled with a cool head and steady aim. Though the Xbox 360 controller is fully supported
column28: the standard keyboard/mouse combo offers vastly superior aiming precision and control
column29: which makes it by far the better option.\n\nRegardless of how similar the combat in Resident Evil 5 is to its predecessor
column30: the addition of a second character makes encounters feel quite different. Teamwork is necessary to take down more powerful enemies and bosses
column31: and having someone to watch your back goes a long way toward keeping you alive. Furthermore
column32: there have been radical changes made to the inventory management system. The immersion-breaking briefcase from the previous game is gone
column33: and enemies no longer politely wait for you to rummage through your things because bringing up your armory doesn't pause the action. Each character can store up to nine items
column34: and as long as you properly organize your inventory using the simple click-and-drag interface
column35: all of your items are only a single keystroke away
column36: which offers an unprecedented level of accessibility to your gear. It's often necessary to trade items with your partner
column37: and keeping track of who has what at all times is crucial
column38:
especially during boss encounters.

Inventory management is easier than ever when you can click and drag items around with your mouse.
Sheva's artificial intelligence makes her a competent companion
column39: though her degree of skill seems to rely more on her armaments than anything else. She is extremely good at using burst fire with a machine gun
column41: but she tends to waste ammo when equipped with a handgun. That said
column42: at no point does she feel like extra baggage that needs babysitting (unlike some of the series' previous companions)
column43: and she can hold her own in a fight. Sheva really shines when there's someone else controlling her. Resident Evil 5 supports online co-op play through Games for Windows Live
column44: and exploring Kijuju with a friend greatly enhances both the experience and the fun factor. Every game has the potential to go multiplayer
column45: since other online players can join in on a free-for-all or invite-only basis if your game session is set up to allow this from the get-go.\n\nDespite these conveniences
column46: there are some frustrating hurdles that need to be leaped over before a partner can begin playing. Co-op isn't drop-in
column48: gameplay is interrupted and immersion is broken to some degree because the player who joined has to sit on the sidelines until the host either restarts or continues on to the next checkpoint. Another major problem is that players' main inventories are isolated from one another
column49: and though you can trade healing items and ammunition
column51:
making some battles more difficult if you're playing with a partner who is not as well equipped as you.

That's it for today. Be sure to read the chapter on gun maintenance--you WILL be tested!
Resident Evil 5 isn't a survival horror game
column52: but that doesn't mean it hasn't learned a great deal from the genre. Tension is the central element of survival horror games
column54: tension has been conveyed by the gloomy settings
column56: and the frustratingly clunky camera angles and controls. All RE5 does differently is convey this feeling through other outlets. Having a partner introduces new types of tension
column57: because you're forced to rely on each other's support
column58: find ways to manage both of your inventories during battles
column59: and cover larger areas since enemies can appear from almost anywhere. Waves of enemies wax and wane with just the right frequency
column60: and while the brightly lit environments make them less scary
column61: they can be tough to deal with because they attack in large numbers and are smarter
column63: and stronger than their counterparts in previous games. Major encounters and boss fights are doled out with excellent pacing
column64: and since you're never sure what to expect around the corner
column65: you have to remain vigilant.\n\nRE5 is one of the most visually stunning games available
column66: and its huge variety of environments is meticulously detailed in every way. There are lots of large
column68: and you'll constantly be on the move through them since there are usually so many enemies. In-game cutscenes are top-notch (though sometimes a bit over-the-top)
column69: and Chris and Sheva are incredibly well animated
column70: especially their faces. If you happen to have the right collection of equipment
column71: you can also take advantage of Nvidia's 3D Vision technology to experience Resident Evil 5 in stereoscopic 3D. The dialogue is often full of the trademark goofiness found in the series. The voice acting is competent
column72: and when paired with the excellent facial expressions
column73: it breathes a great deal of realism into the characters. Likewise
column74: the fantastic orchestral soundtrack heightens the gameplay with everything from the low-key
column75: ambient tracks that play during downtimes to the frantic
column76:
upbeat songs that accompany the massive boss battles.

THE GOOD
Beautifully detailed graphics and character animations
Having a partner enhances the fun and excitement while adding tension
Real-time menu system keeps you immersed
Plenty to do once you've beaten it
Superior keyboard/mouse controls

THE BAD
Frustrating hurdles to leap when joining an online game
Slow
column77:
deliberate movement and gunplay may not appeal to everyone

8.5"

reviewText: Tried my damnedest to get this game to work, and by all rights it should, I get 200 FPS+ on the variable benchmark test in game, but any time I try to press the system settings button on the main menu, or at no less than a minute into a game, my game crashes.\nI have tried my very hardest trying to troubleshoot this, I looked at Capcom's official steam posts, traipsed the internet for a couple hours, tried manually installing components, completely uninstalling and reinstalling -three times-, verifying my game cache, and absolutely nothing worked.\nDo not buy this broken console port of a game, riddled with a dead middleman called Games for Windows Live. I love RE5, but I'm working on trying to see if I can get a refund on this purchase ASAP.

reviewText: Short Version: Fun co-op experience. Basically a simplified rehash of RE4's best bits with updated graphics .\n\nLong Version: Looks extremely pretty. Inventory management is simplified. Merchant is gone replaced by a end of chapter shop. AI partner is ok, but best played with another human. Many scenarios & boss fights are recycled from RE4 but less fun. An entire level is on rails turret shooting including the boss fight with El Gigante, who makes no sense appearing in this game. Giant insects are back but are weaker & less mobile. Weapons are varied & can be upraded. If u liked RE4 then u might like this game. U can see the first signs of RE turning into a action game, but this is still miles better than RE6.

reviewText: If you know me well, I absolutely HATE replaying games over and over again, but this game... I have played over and over, I know most of what happens but when I go back to replay it, it feels brand new to me. Possibly the BEST coop game created, it is perfectly styled and executed with coop in mind, obviously there are drawbacks as the story isn't too long but is long enough and interesting enough to keep you thinking and wondering what will happen. The only big complaint I have is that it starts out as a horror, but ends up being a big action game, which isn't bad but its just my personal opinion. Overall if you haven't played this yet I would.\n\n9.5/10

reviewText:
While I am no dedicated fan of the Resident Evil series, nor an everyday follower, I hear many cite Resident Evil 5 as the beginning of what they felt was a decline. Having only foggy childhood memories of Resident Evil 2 on my old Nintendo 64 and a close friend's dedication to the series holding me back, I can still say I understand why.

It is no secret that I am one for action games with good tempo and flow; the countless hours I've invested into Payday, E.Y.E., and Killing Floor speak volumes. I am no stranger to horror; I've played the far ends of the spectrum in Amnesia and Penumbra, Dead Space and STALKER. Even as restrained as I can be, I can say wholeheartedly that Resident Evil 5 struck none of the high notes that any of those titles - for all the hours and playthroughs they've offered me - have achieved.

While undoubtedly far in advance of the fixed camera perspective I recall from Resident Evil 2, Resident Evil 5's combat hit me as clunky, backwards, and bizarrely slow. Clunky, where the player is rooted to the ground while firing and is most often required to use slow-firing manual and semiautomatic weapons. Backwards, where headshots are passively discouraged by the early introduction of particular reactions to headshots. Bizarrely slow, where mentioned focus on pistols and pump-action shotguns combines with a dawdling enemy pace that would make some of my slowest games in strategy titles seem like they were taking place at superluminal velocity.

Storywise, I doubt I have ever cringed as much as I have through the course of watching Resident Evil 5's plot. It is easily the most unashamedly cheesy and melodramatic game I have ever played, bereft of humor and serious to a fault. In some cases, I saw plot elements coming from miles away. In others, I could feel the word why" trying to beat its way out of my skull. Particularly
date: a character is introduced early on with all the subtlety and rationality in design as a tank skydiving into a ballpit. As the plot continued to thicken
recommended: I could feel my "immersion" - had I even pretended to carry any - shrivel further and further.\n\nBogging down gameplay and storytelling yet more are the absurdly numerous and absurdly lengthy quick-time events that sometimes boggled the mind as to why they even existed. Events such as the player characters running down hallways became
voteText: interactive cutscenes
helpfulPercent: rather than allowing player control and offering meaningful challenges over button mashing contests and keyboard (or controller) attention checks. While I do not deny that Dead Space - oft-compared and of similar genre definition - featured many of its own quick-time events
votesHelpful: I feel much more confident in their role and value than I do Resident Evil 5's.\n\nThe game is not without its strengths

column20: but unfortunately play to one of the game's weak suits - its combat - outside of regular cooperative play.\n\nIn conclusion

reviewText:
Resident Evil 4 massively broke the formula. Whilst there were some complaints from the diehards, the overwhelming census was that the franchise's break away from fixed camera was for the best. Whilst their recent titles Code Veronica and Resident Evil 0 were decent enough, but not amazing, RE4 found audiences every bit as awe struck by the game as they were when they first stepped foot in Spenser Manor in 1996. The franchise looked onward to a bright new future that whilst certainly would leave its survival horror roots behind, would immerse it's audience in a detailed 3D world with tight new gunplay as they fought back overwhelming hordes of Mexicans Spaniards.
Alas, the dream was too good to be true. RE5 was merely a mediocre third person shooter with nothing more than an arbitrary RE universe story featuring some familiar faces. The fantastic difficulty balance and pacing of the battles seen in its predecessor  were absent, and the distinctly Japanese over the top story and set pieces were replaced with Western feeling low key blandness. Whilst some areas such as the swampy island area offered enjoyable large scale battles, much of the game was spent trudging down corridors spraying a continual stream of bullets.
The biggest upside to this title is that coop mode plays very well, and overcoming a difficult spot with teamwork on the harder difficulties feels very rewarding. Also, it means you won't have to put up with the immersion breaking ai ineptitude of Sheva.

Spear-chucking Mud Men out of Ten

***Fun Stuff for RE Fans***
Check out where the series really got it's root's from by playing Sweet Home on the NES (or at least an English rom on an emulator...). It's a survival horror RPG in which a team of characters explore a haunted mansion (which is refereed to as a 'House of Residing Evil'!). You have limited inventory space, one character has a permanent lock pick, one has a permanent lighter, and the only way to heal if to carry the limited number of inventory hogging healing items you find. Also, doors open slowly in first person. Any of that sound familiar to veterans of the series? Its a far better, and far scarier experience than RE5!

reviewText:
Resident Evil 5 had a rough start. The media bashed the game before it even saw the light of day for It's racism towards the African people that the trailers showed. Once the game came out, you heard no more complaints about racisim. What you had, was another pretty good Resident Evil game.
The story is your standard Resident Evil tale, Wesker is up to no good and its up to (Chris) and his new partner (Sheva) to stop him. The combat can be exciting tho still feels trapped in the past, Not being able to walk and shoot is a small complaint, but Dead Space has showed us how important it is and it just makes sence. Now with a friend this game can be pretty amazing at time, tho playing solo, it feels like the AI is holding you back and is only good for using as a second inventory.
If you have a friend to play this with and can get passed some of the old trappings this series still faces, you'll be in for a fun time.
Personal Rating: 4/5

reviewText:
While the plot isn't exactly anything to write home about, if you come to an RE game expecting anything but a B Movie plotline than you're being a bit silly. The gameplay is smooth, the gunplay solid, and even if it's very much an action title it is still a very fun game, especially in co-op. The weapons feel different from one another, even in the same category, and the enemies force you to approach them with some thinking and care even from the start. Ammo can and will end up scarce, forcing you to utilize more varied means of engaging your enemies and being a bit more selective in just what weapons you use when. However, enemies are tough enough that most players will feel the need to actually make use of weapons besides their handgun and knife, which is nice.

All in all I consider RE5 to be a fun game, even if it's not necessarily what I want from a Resident Evil game. I haven't expected to get that anymore ever since they ditched the original RE4 idea and went with Leon's Magical Adventures in Espania, which is admittedly also a very, very good game and a lot of fun.

Summary Score: 8/10 where 0 is legitimately harmful to the user, 5 is 'average', and 10 is the absolute best of its kind.

reviewText: In the latest years, Capcom has been gradually moving Resident Evil franchise from the survival horror into coop shooter genre (not without zombies, of course), maybe to add more to it, maybe to attract more players. Anyway, Resident Evil 5 is like a cornerstone that marks the transition. It's a great game, indeed, but maybe Capcom forgets that while a cooperative game (or single-player with a partner) can be a bit scary, it can't be that much of a horror game than when player is alone.\nRecommended to play with a friend.

reviewText: Though looked down upon by die-hard Resident Evil fans, I have to admit that I had a blast with Resident Evil 5. This series has always verged on camp, but here Capcom really takes the ridiculousness to a new level. Chris Redfield now punches boulders and careens over lava with superhuman ease. The dialogue sends me into fits of laughter. And the boss fights are fantastic fun. Sure, it's hardly a survival horror at this point, but to me the original games were never really all that scary to begin with (they ain't Silent Hill, that's for sure). If you weren't expect another coming of RE4, RE5 does its job well. 8/10
