reviewText: I didn't play Resident Evil 5 much at the moment the game came out, although I've bought it and then somehow lost it. Recently I've bought Resident Evil 6 to play with and was more than pleased with the game mechanics, cutscenes, voice acting and more action-orentied gameplay (with both tight and fluid keyboard and mouse controls) than classic chapters of Resident Evil. I played all the classic chapters on PC and PSX and always loved the franchise, either it was a horror-survival or action-survival game. After beating Resident Evil 6, getting all the achievements, all skills and all of other stuff, I wanted to try the preceding chapter, so I bought Resident Evil 5 second time, now both the main game and the gold edition add-on to have this game with Steamworks support. Turned out that the game is actually better than sequel and more fun too, I've beaten the game on all four difficulties with S-rank, I bought and upgraded almost all weapons, now heading to get all those achivements. Back to the game - the camera is under your full control, no annoying director" in your way like in RE6
date: way less QTE moments but they look awkward on keyboard. You cannot walk while shoot (remember - I've already played Dead Space and Resident Evil 6 at this moment) but the devs were taking it into account so it works really well. The only drawback is your AI partner
recommended: which can be pretty annoying on Professional difficulty - you'll be hearing "Shevaaa!" a lot as she will die from the sunbeam in 4th chapter most of the time. Damn

reviewText:
This game is great, where else but Resident evil/Biohazard could you get chris redfield smashing great big rocks with his bear hands??? ahh it's very realistic indeed.

I've had more time in this game but had to play a large chuck of the action offline.

Anyway the PC port is considered quite bad for a number of reasons HOWEVER, if you are a fan and havent played it yet, why not?!! only kidding, treat yourself to the game, yes there are some issues but the game is perfectly playable unfortunately the Co-op is non existant outside of a patch that was created for the game not sure if it still works.

I enjoyed the game mostly but some plot elements were OTT for the sake of it and laughable quotes to remember YOUR STRUGGLE IS OVER" (he said with gnarling teeth) and many more flavours to be had.

This direction should have kept what the series is and has been known for but it became so action orientated it wasn't really survival horror anymore
date: personally enjoy the mercenaries mode more than the main game itself and always worth playing again to shut that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ irving up
recommended:
his face makes you want to puke and that's as a human.......


This game is definately not the mess Biohazard 6 became which was all over the shop and without a real sense of plot direction and even further moved away from the survival horror genre. If it's not horror-esque enough for you then try the spin off series "revalations" for a more macarbe horror induced experience like the good old glory days of the series.

I enjoyed it for what it's worth and it's worth the money and your attention.

Thank you."

reviewText: The port is great but with one major problem. Occasionally the video will have collision issues causing the screen to completely screw up making it impossible to see anything in the game. The only way to fix it is to either restart the game or minimize the game then re-enlarge it. voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is so much fun!!!

Lets get started then, first Campaign.
The campaign is pretty good considering that its not a true Resi game. I enjoyed the campaign so much im playing it again. Yes the AI for Sheva may be clumsy from time to time so you may be better off playing with a friend. There is also collectable emblems which unlocks costumes for Chris and Sheva.

Bonus Modes.
There isn't that many bonus modes added in Resident Evil 5 but the mercenaries mode is enjoyable. They have also added a No Mercy mode just for PC. There is plenty of maps to play on the mercenaries mode and it is replayable as you can feel like you can get a much better score than your previous score. In the story mode you start off with 3 difficulties. Once you complete veteren mode you unlock professional mode which just seems darn impossible.

Verdict.
Resident Evil 5 may not be like the other Resident Evil game but it is a fun one. Mainly built for co-op its still fun when you play solo. The game does have a few issues with Enemys and Shevas AI from time to time but its still worth checking out.

(My score 8.5/10)
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Quick rundown: Resident Evil 5 continues the evolution of the Resident Evil series into more action than horror. If you’ve played Resident Evil 4 and wanted better controls, better graphics, and more gunfire, you’ll enjoy RE 5. They’ve also refined the combat system so you don’t spend as much time knifing people lying on the ground because ammo is a lot less of a problem this time around (overall). You still run out of ammo in the middle of some missions, but you can quit and reload, getting access to your stash. Note that RE 5 is the kind of game you where you can keep load and replay specific chapters to grind for money and ammo. If you have a co-op partner the game is much more fun since the entire campaign can be played with a friend (or a stranger). Games for Windows Live has been stripped out of the Steam version by the way, but it’s not perfectly done.

The game’s story follows Chris Redfield as he battles his way through various hostile environments in Africa with his new partner Sheva. Chris is an officer in the BSAA, investigating the apparent use of bioweapons in the area, and by bioweapon I don’t mean Ebola or Super Aids. Ouroboros is a world ending super virus aimed at culling the “inferior” humans from the planet (by adding their biomass to giant monsters). Most of Chris’ enemies seems to be infected with the Las Plagas parasite that Leon Kennedy encountered in Resident Evil 4, turning people into slow moving “rage zombies” that follow the orders of mysterious bad guys. That’s not all though since the virus can also cause grotesque mutations, and advanced versions can create monstrous giant bosses. If you’ve watched the Resident Evil movie series or played the previous games, you’ll recognize the big boss of Resident Evil 5, and even some of the fight scenes seem to have been ripped off for the movies.

Like Resident Evil 4, this game is played in third person but unlike part 4, Resident Evil 5 was built with 2-player co-op in mind.  Throughout the campaign, you play either Chris or Sheva, and the computer AI (or a friend) controls the other character. Sheva is unlocked for single player after beating the game but can be played immediately in co-op. You’ll be fighting side by side 95% of the time but occasionally split up in scripted areas. During these short periods, you’ll be much more vulnerable because not only do you not have a partner covering your back, you also don’t have anyone to revive you if you take too much damage and go down.

As I mentioned earlier you get a lot more ammunition in this game than in RE 4, which means you’ll be shooting a lot more as well. Be warned that your computer controlled partner fires their weapons a lot, possibly eating up all your ammo. Both characters have their own 9 slot inventory and can freely swap items between them. Between levels, you have the opportunity to modify your inventory by moving things into a persistent “stash” that can hold infinite items. This way, you can always start a level with what you need and don’t have to sell off your stuff to make room like in RE 4. In RE 4 your inventory was just too small to hold all the guns and ammo. I also mentioned before that you can replay levels at will, which means if you know there’s lots of ammo or money in a certain level you can farm it over and over. By the end you should have more ammo than you will ever need, but money (for upgrading guns) will always be in short supply.

Pros:
+Great game for co-op if you have a friend that you want to play through the campaign with. The game allows you to save your inventory separately when you quit a level. This means if you realize you’ve wasted too much ammo and want to quit without saving, you can. This also means you can start a level, grab all the goodies in the starting area, and save + quit.
+Faster paced than Resident Evil 4. I enjoy action games, and RE 5 plays a lot more like Dead Space, where you need to constantly be on your guard against getting mobbed. Aiming, reaction speed, and choosing your next move in the thick of combat (take advantage of invincibility animations!) are all important skills.
+Excellent graphics (horrible monsters) and a decent storyline. You also get the Mercenaries mini game unlocked after beating the campaign. You can spend a lot of time on this game mode.

Cons:
-You will need to replay some levels to get the money/ammo necessary to advance in the game. I didn’t mind because I like farming for items, but some people may not appreciate that you HAVE TO replay levels during your first playthrough. It takes about 15 hours to beat the game because of all the replay, even though actually running through each level would probably end the game in about 5 hours.
-The game was formerly tied to Games for Windows Live, and even though that requirement has been stripped out of the Steam version, it still tries to launch GFWL on startup of the game. Steam gives you a product key to enter for GFWL, except the GFWL doesn’t exist. There’s also a little DOS window that says something about module not found every time I play the game. This is just a minor annoyance, but it seems like something they ought to have fixed.
-Alas, a lot of the game’s Steam achievements are tied to the DLC Untold Stories, which costs almost as much as the base game.

Overall, the game is a lot of fun, and if you get into it you can spend 25 hours easily just unlocking all the weapons, and even more playing the Mercenaries mode. You’ll enjoy the experience a lot more with a co-op partner than by yourself.

reviewText:
This hands down, has to be my favorite Resident Evil game to come to PC. The smooth co-op factor made this stand out quite a bit, aside from the occasional connection issues due to running windows live through steam and what not, though works brilliantly the rest of the time.

Now, as for story-line, I really did enjoy the fact it didn't go for the stereotypical crew of Leon, Ada etc, as much as I love those characters, I find there wasn't ever enough about Chris Redfield and Sheva Alomar (A local BSAA agent), though maybe that is just me. This game revolves around Chris and Sheva's investigation of a terrorist threat in Kijuju, a fictional place in Africa, giving it a really nice rural environment from the get go.

Through the RE games, they seemed to lose their horror and survival aspect, but RE 5 manages to bring back a eerie tension with it's mechanics, keeping you on your toes from start to finish. I loved this. The boss fights were actually quite intense, a little bit creepy when you are being chased down in tight area's and with little ammo to spare and find, after all, you don't just find random clips of ammo lying down in the real world, do you?

Enemies no longer politely wait for you to rummage through your things either, because bringing up your armory doesn't pause the action, which brings back the survival feeling to the game, because if you aren't carefully watching when going through your inventory to switch between weapons, you will die. Also, the fact you can't carry THAT many weapons compared to a lot of games which take an RPG and a range of other weapons and just put them in their back pocket to continue sprinting and running like nothing.

It brings some amazing visuals and a few enhancements, In other words, kind of like what RE3 was to RE2. The monsters aren't that imaginative, though lickers get brought back!

To the action aspect, your partner can revive you, relatively quick weapon swapping, colossal bosses and the horror-ish aspect is pulled off with limited controls and the classic over-the-shoulder view, an inventory system that doesn't pause to make enemies wait whilst you ready yourself for them and some pretty intense puzzle solving whilst trying to stay alive.

In all, amazing game, loved the new mechanics, great co-op and the revamp of the creepy horror, survival aspects.

reviewText:
This game is likely one of my guilty pleasures. I know people tend to hate the 'new' Resident Evils, but I happen to really like them.

Prior to playing it on PC, I played it at least a 100 hours on Xbox, going through everything to get a 100% complete rating and all the achievments. Sadly, the appeal of those things are.. well.. gone, with this version.

Sure, it was a fun run through but the lack of friends actually owning this port left me playing by myself. Which is good, but not nearly as fun as with someone else. That, and this version lacks the DLC all together. Two missions with new characters, new outfits, new challenges, and new filters, are all gone, the menu they used to be in still actually present in the game like it should've been there.

To keep it short, I recommend you get it for cheap with a friend and play it through; it's still a great game despite allk the hate.

[Update] I wrote this review several months ago, and as of that point, the DLC has become available. I don't recommend buying it for the price it's at as it is an old DLC set for full price for a game no one really liked, but if it ever goes on sale along with the game, it's worth a playthrough for sure.

reviewText:
If you're looking for a twitch shooter, then look elsewhere. Aiming forces your character to remain stationary.

As for being a turret defense simulator, I find the lack of variety in guns disturbingly low. Is there a DLC for more guns?

Pro-tip: Put game on easy mode, and stand in front of a group of zombies. Knife them, and they won't be able to fight back. You can win the entire game doing this.

reviewText: Resident Evil 5 is the one RE game that just didn't grab my attention and in turn has taken me so long to finally start playing. The DLC that was released recently is what got me to really start playing. I really want to check out those DLC levels that take you back to the Spencer Estate. The game itself is very fast paced but the battles are fun once you get the hang of the inventory being used while in game instead of essentially pausing the game as in previous games. This adds challenge while also making the game that much more in the moment. The flaw of this game is the AI of your CPU partner. The only real way to play this is with a friend in co-op mode. I would recommend this game if you're like me and have to have everything Resident Evil. However, if you don't like what you've seen of the game and how fast paced it is, you may not think very highly of it.

reviewText:
Old game but its great. Now with steamworks. You can transfer your old saves, achievments and equipment from games for windows live which is great! got my few thousand bullets for each gun back :P
It's got incredible replayability value which has been increased with new dlc that was console exclusive. The graphic is acceptably nice (and can be tweaked like blur and hdr in the .ini file to High to make it look even better).
After all these years this is still one of best resident evil games (better than 6 anyway).

Pros:
+ nice story
+ full story coop!
+ now with steamworks!
+ huge replayability value
+ acceptable graphics
+ consle exclusive dlc is out for pc's thanks to steam! (not microsoft which didnt care!)
+ controller support
+ mercenary mode which has been expanded with more content thx to the dlc
+ really hard professional difficulty

Cons:
- outdated controls from 2003 (not an issue once get used to)
- extremely dumb ai
- too short story :P

9/10

Revelations 2 RAID mode picks up from greatness of RE5 mercenary mode and improves it hugely. Those two games have the best raid modes in entire series (at least for me)

To sum things up, Resident Evil 5 is a classic game that will not dissapoint you and will deliver countless hours of fun solo or with friends. It is definetly worth every penny!

Hawthorne School of Aeronautics is a closed flying school/airport located 5 miles south of Orangeburg, South Carolina. The school was closed in 1945. Today the land is being used for non-aviation purposes.

The Hawthorne School of Aeronautics was a World War II civilian flying school, contracted by the United States Army Air Forces to conduct primary pilot training for aviation cadets. The school was under the supervision of the 58th Flying Training Detachment, Eastern Flight Training Center, Army Air Forces Training Command. The president of Hawthorne was Beverly Bevo" Howard

reviewText: A great game that allows people to coop both story mode and the mercenaries giving players plenty of hours of enjoyment. What i really enjoyed with this game is being able to use multiple weapons and keeping them so i can upgrade and eventually use unlimited ammo with them, which is completly optional; Resident Evil 5 has its faults too starting with the number of items avaliable to use is much smaller than the briefcase mechanic used in Resident Evil 4, but the trade off here is Resident Evil 5 allows players to keep their weapons outside of missions while Resident Evil 4's is dependent on the amount of space the player's breifcase has. The only bad mechanics i found with this game is needing to mod the game for online versus, mercenaries, team surival etc. because the aiming is off, needing to mod for the laser sights for story mode because the laser sights is only avaiable if playing with a controller, and bugs like map clipping and sequences not working properly. If you can overlook those small caviots then i would recommend this game and strongly recommend cooping with another player.

reviewText:
Having played this for 400+ plus hours on the Xbox 360 (and I'll probably be ending up with the same if not more on Steam since steamworks is almost finished) I can safely say this is one of my favourite entries in the Resident Evil franchise.

Yes, it's not Resident Evil 4 but to me Resi 4 was EXTREMELY overrated. Its been released 3 times for gods sake. I didnt really enjoy 4 and  Leon is my least favourite character ever

Resi 5 doesnt have the horror of the first few games but thats not a reason to not buy 5. 5 is a gem on its own.

The story is cheesy but in a good way. The locations are great through out the game, always changing. The characters are fantastic although Sheva does start to get a little annoying towards the end.

People often complain about how and why Chris is so beefy. I mean c'mon, he's got Albert f*cking Wesker as a nemesis! Chris got his ♥♥♥ handed to him back in Code Veronica!

Anyway, all in all this game is fantastic. Its got a ton of replay value. The weapons upgrading is a neat little system that will keep you busy. There's also Mercenaries when you've finished the story and that will keep you occupied for days. And as Im writing this review, Steam achievements have just been added and they include all DLC achievements too.

So when Resi 5 is moved to steamworks, you'll have even more content to play with!

Lost in Nightmares is fantastic, it tells the story of when Chris and Jill went to find Ozwell E Spencer and is creepy as hell.

Desperate Escape is just as good too, telling you how Josh and Jill escaped near the end.

Then theres also Mercenaries Reunion and Versus mode. There is an absolute ton to do on this game. I've 100% this game at least 5 times and I'd gladly do it all over again.

If you dont mind the missing element of survival horror then get this entry, for the love of god man.

Thank me later.

Saturation/10

reviewText:
Death by reloading

RE5 is a great game spoiled by atrocious controls. I mean the worst ever. These are the main problems: You can’t move while reloading, aiming, or shooting; instead you become rooted to the spot and therefore hopelessly vulnerable to attack. When aiming the sight is often (although, oddly, not always) wrenched away from the point already centred so you have to find your target again. And you can’t jump or crouch unless prompted. What the hell is that all about? Also the AI is pretty poor. Sheva gets in the way more often than not. The UI looks like something out of the 90s and is clunky to say the least. And you can’t access the inventory during gameplay (although I understand the reasoning behind this it is frustrating at times). So what is there to like? Well it looks amazing. The graphics are among the best I’ve ever seen, with particularly impressive character models and animations. And, controls aside, the gameplay is enjoyable, with a good selection of environments, some pretty tough bosses, and a range of simple but enjoyable puzzles to solve. Ammo is often scarce so you have to be more thoughtful about your approach to the combat than in many games. Overall it’s a top-flight game marred only but it’s poorly designed controls and interface. Sadly these are so bad I can only give it 3 out of 5, which is a real shame.

3/5

reviewText:
As a masochist, I find this game infernal and for that reason very pleasing. Visually, it holds up very well, despite being 5 years old now. It was commonly used as a benchmark for GPUs.

Most of the classic mechanics are here. The Capcom philosophy of survival horror, that is, creating difficulty through sluggish control, is bad design, but somehow it works here. Of course, unlike in many modern games, health does not regenerate. You also have your infernal inventory in which to store your weapons and items.

The game really shines in co-op such that I'd say it's the best way to play it for the first time. Aside from one or two uninspired boss encounters as well as some more minor gripes, any masochist will enjoy this game.

reviewText:
Those of you who're thinking of buying this game because you played and enjoyed RE4, turn around and walk away now. Let me explain to you why RE5 is NOTHING compared to RE4.

I enjoyed RE4 immensely, I've played it hours and completed it 100% on all difficulties. After reading a few (in hindsight VERY MISLEADING) reviews, thought I'd enjoy RE5 as well. But boy was I wrong.

First of all, there's no story. Or nearly no story. You just go from A to B and shoot things. Don't expect an intriguing story like I did, having played RE4 before. After a few chapters it'll get very repetitive.
Also, there's no creepy, scary feel to the game. Everything seems to be in broad daylight, there wasn't even a single point in the game that I was hesitant/too scared to progress. Just run and shoot, easy.

Second, while the overall controls are similar to RE4, which I like, they now put in a HORRIBLE inventory system. Not only does it look and feel very very cheap and unfinished, it's more of a hassle than an additional challenge of good inventory management, like it was in RE4.

Third, the bosses and enemies are just, so, boring. It's like they used the least imaginative, probably cheapest, artists to create the monsters and bosses. Just expect slimy black tentacles. Yey.
And I could've accepted this boring monster-design fact, if these bosses would at least prove a challenge to kill. But no, they threw in gatling guns everywhere to kill the bosses. You don't even have to rely on your gunmanship skills anymore, you just point and shoot with the gatling gun. YAWN.

Fourth, I expect they ran out of ideas, because they just filled in some levels with vehicles: drive a jeep and shoot a gatling gun. Urgh. Steer a ship and shoot a gatling gun. Sigh. Stand on a deck and shoot a gatling gun. Whoop.

Fifth: there aren't any cool weapons in this game. Each weapon feels like you're holding a toy gun, they don't sound good, they don't look good. And the upgrades aren't interesting like they were in RE4, because there aren't even exclusive upgrades anymore when maxing out your gun!

The only thing I really enjoyed in this game is the melee attacks you can perform with your buddy online. Stun an enemy, punch him in the face. And if it's a stronger enemy, you can both unleash your melee actions on it, for even greater damage. Aaand that's really about the only positive thing I have to say about this game.

So I think I'm clear: RE4 fans, don't do this to yourself, don't buy this game. Even the multiplayer, which is the reason why I bought this game, doesn't make up for all it's flaws.

It's like a mental cringe, each time you discover how bad it is compared to RE4. It's a waste of money.

reviewText:
One of the greatest Resident Evil games IMO. It may not be a Survival Horror game anymore, but the coop is awesome. One of the best action coop games I've played so far. Great amount of weapons, nice extra missions (like BSAA emblems and treasures), and good online after the main story with The Mercenaries. Archievements are also good, and it takes some time to get them all.

RE6 may be newest, I still prefer this one. Not being able to move while you shoot or reload your weapon make it special and different of other action games, and it's something characteristic of the saga.

I'll never get tired of this game when I have someone to play with. Totally recommened!

reviewText: So, I heard a lot of stories about this game and they weren't good ones. It's not Resident Evil anymore" they said. "Resident Evil 4 is better than this" they said. "Every Resident Evil after the 4th iteration is bad" they said. And what can I say? They're not right. It's as simple as that.\n\nAs harsh as this truth may be
date: Resident Evil has shifted its focus from classic survival horror to a more action oriented gameplay experience. But this already happened after Resident Evil 3: Nemesis. The fixed camera angles are missing in favor of a 3rd person perspective
recommended: the classic zombies from the first three games are no more and the story of the Umbrella corporation ended long before the setting of Resident Evil 4. So it shouldn't come as a surprise that Resident Evil 5
voteText: is more action oriented than the classic Resident Evil titles.\n\nIn fact

votesFunny: the graphics are more advanced

column24: compared to the Resident Evil 4 inventory when maxed out. You got nine inventory slots in total which means that you can only afford to take 3 weapons with you at most
column25: I recommend carrying 2 weapons for each character so that you can still fit in first aid spray/herbs and grenades - or a bullet proof vest.\n\nAlso
column26: the merchant from Resident Evil 4 is gone
column27: that iconic figure. You will be missed. Aside from that
column28: the health bar system is different
column29: too. Instead of featuring a segmented bar which can be increased by consuming yellow herbs in combination with green herbs and red herbs
column30: you have a full bar with a set amount of health - rendering the yellow herb obsolete in the process
column31: which is why it was removed.\n\nBut aside from all this... Resident Evil 5 plays like Resident Evil 4 - just a little bit more simplified and with better looks. The puzzles

reviewText:
A solid co-op TBS that gets a lot of blind hate from Resident Evil purists, and more deservingly, from those that say it's a reskinned and lesser version of Resident Evil 4.

Despite that, I found it thoroughly enjoyable, playing through the game multiple times, and accruing more than 100 hours. This is thanks in large part to: Impressive visuals, a fantastic porting job (game runs silky smooth even on average hardware), addictive and responsive shootan/melee mechanics, enjoyable co-op, large weapon variety and customisation and one of the greatest bossfights ever (7 minute Wesker <3)

It is brought down somewhat with cutscene QTEs, mandatory on-rails shooting segments, hamfisted cover system in the last quarter of the game and not having nearly enough Wesker.

Mercenaries mode is also balls to the wall awesome, plenty of unlockable levels and characters (and you get to play as Weskerfu :3c)

reviewText: Zombie blasting fun. The good news: the graphics are great, the gameplay keeps you engaged and the music really works. The bad news: the story is okay at best, the AI is dumb and the inventory system made me want to shoot my partner, not to mention the whole armor issue. Recommended if you're a RE fan and worth a go even if you haven't kept up with the story. And if nothing else, Sheva is always fun to just gawk at.

reviewText:
Resident Evil 5 is very much a love it or hate it part of the Resident Evil franchise. There are many reasons for this, most notably starting with Resident Evil 4 and the series departure from pure scare tactics into a more story driven, fight off zombie hordes sort of affair.

I find that this sort of evolution actually makes sense as the games stay contained within the same universe. When zombies, the c-virus, las plagas, etc become common knowledge, it becomes much harder for the characters in that world to become outright scared. This also translates to the players growing up with the games. Whether it was the dogs jumping through windows in Resident Evil 1, the menacing lickers of RE2 or the constant stress of being hunted down by Nemesis in RE3, we've grown up with this series and it's very hard to throw a curve ball at us. We aren't the 10-14 year olds with wild imaginations anymore.

So with Resident Evil 5, it follows the natural course of, we know there are weird creatures afoot, it's down to us to locate the source to try and put an end to it. And I find the story telling and voice acting to be very well done. It can be a bit campy but Resident Evil 5 wasn't going for a The Last of Us" feel or story narrative.

Now when it comes to gameplay

reviewText:
A slightly souless successor to the epic Resident Evil 4. Resident Evil 5 stumbles around trying to recreate what was loved about Resident Evil 4, either by adapting from certain elements or completely copying the exact same events.

Thing is that it sort of works. You have the same combat as Res 4, same sort of atmosphere and style, it's all in there and works in the gameplay's favour. However Resident Evil 5's major flaw is that it seriously lacks the charm and personality Resident Evil 4 flourished in. In story, Resident Evil 4 comes across as a B-movie with a sense of self-awarness that the Resident Evil series should pretty much just always have considering how blatently stupid the writing is (although funny as hell). Resident Evil 5 once again starts trying to take itself seriously in it's story and enviroment which doesn't really help since the story this time around has lost any of the mystery elements that kept Resident Evil 4's balance of action and horror and is now more action oriented when now it's more about straight up saving the world from ultra bad guy man person.

Resident Evil 4 had it's set pieces moving at a very good rate. Soon enough while in the Village it becomes night, as new terrors emerge from the darkness, or the island and how  you delve deeper into gruesome and sickening labratories  and of course there is the Castle to which any absurd thing can be just slammed right in there at any moment. It's designed in such a way that anything could be in the next room.

Resident Evil 5 doesn't really have anything new or continiously varied to it, and with the atmosphere now being kind of dead, there isn't too much to be remembered. The game for the most part repeats the same set pieces (Village, mines, labs) without adding to much to the mix or having the same twists and turns each place could have. There is really nothing in this game that could take you by suprise.

Is the game fun? I guess it depends from how much you can get out of it. It's more arcadey this time around, more bent on action than survival and atmosphere, plus a new co-op feature which at the most is neat and occasionally enjoyable" while also being "a completely destructing element". Cooping with a buddy CAN be fun
date: sure all atmosphere of horror is now completely dead and burried at least 60 feet under concrete

That's about it. It will shoot the things

You take the pistol away from her forcing the AI to use the other weapons. It's actually really astounding.\n\nWell

reviewText:
I bought this game when it first came out, and have loved it from the moment I first played it.

HOWEVER I am rather irked by this recent transfer to Steam.

I have at least 1000 hours worth of play, and I got every single achievement when it was on Windows Live. It took a lot of hard work, cooperation from a friend and time to get all of the achievments, and I was rather proud to have gotten them all.

Now I have to pay £11 for the DLC, (Which has taken since 2008 to create for PC) which is twice as much money as the game in its stand alone state, and I have to re-do all of the achievements, that are not transfered over from Windows Live, even though they are the exactly the same.

Why do I have the feeling I have been taken for a ride?!

reviewText:
Like Resident Evil 4 except tedious and awful.  --It feels  washed out and grey, with much less variety (hey, another African village/town!), with an inexplicable filter applied to exacerbate the issue, while RE4 had more colors and more environments.
--RE4 had  a stand-alone story, and a self aware sense of humor about its own absurdity, where RE5 takes itself too seriously and expects you to care about its absurdly convoluted lore.
--RE4 designed  its gameplay around having to stop to shoot to raise the tension, while RE5 feels like it's designed for a more modern third-person control scheme (especially in single player) but kept the controls because RE4 had them and people like(d) RE4.
--Many of  the enemies are reskins of RE4 (and even RE2) enemies; the European villagers are now African; the Los Plagas looks less like a fleshy contorted blob and more like a centipede; The El Gigante has hair (and a turret section because everybody loves those, right?). The only interesting enemies (the new ones) are absent for most of the first half of the game (unless putting stereotypical Tribal African getups on enemies counts).
--The game  is crushingly linear, and  the locations are sterile and empty, compunded by the really gamey" way you can quit out to a loadout selector and shop when you die/complete a chapter. There's little incentive to look around and the environments are rarely interesting enough to warrant your attention. RE4 had bigger and more detailed environments
date: with hidden things and at least had you buy things from a person (and made you wait for long stretches before you could buy supplies). On top of that
recommended: there were multiple routes around and even branching paths (like when you choose between a pth leading past an El Gigante or one past the Chainsaw Sisters
hoursPlayed: or even in th opening in the village when where you run to changes what you fight).\n--RE5 added  co-op
voteText: but made almost no meaningful changes from RE4 to accomodate this
helpfulPercent: bar one neat section early on where one character holds a light and the other shoots
votesHelpful: . The co-op does nothing to improve the game
votesTotal: and even infects the single player where you must deal with (and share supplies with) an unbelievably braindead AI partner
votesFunny: even worse than Ashley from RE4\n--RE4 had  some pretty decent puzzles
commentsCount: but RE5 seems to think "put key in door" is a puzzle.\n--The bosses  are not nearly as fun or well-presented as RE4
column16: and yet agin
column17: the only interesting ones wait until too late in the game.\nTL;DR There is  nothing  this game does that RE4 didn't do better; it's a soulless and pitiful imitation. This game gets a  4/10  because it is technically functional

column19: just get RE4."

reviewText:
It's strange how the direction to Resident Evil has changed so dramatically. From what amounts to open world exploration, with the need to gather keys, and clues, to uncover more passages; to an outright liner level design, with no doubling-back, and actual individule stages. It's just very strange, more than anything! As well--though Resident Evil. . .3, or was it zero? handled partners well, in this version it removes all the tension and fear, because you're very alert AI companion is by your side virtually at all times, and in fact I just stopped looking for enemies myself because I knew my partner would see them before I often would.

It should be called. .something else; a different series, with different characters; because that's what it feels like. It could be successful if that's what it was, but what's here does not really feel like an actual Resident Evil game, and that's really the very worse thing about it!

I don't know what the project leads were thinking, but perhaps they were actually turned into zombies during production. Especially the later levels feel, just not well thought out in basic ways. Like, there's these just knee-high walls preventing you from travelling across the path, and you simply can not cross them, even though any human--or zombie--could just step over those walls! It was really my greatest memory of the game, after the first level; just standing there, saying to my character: Leon
recommended: just. . . just step over that wall. . .Leon
voteText: please. . . please. . .you're a super special-ops trained officer; you've travelled across the world
helpfulPercent: fighting monsters! Look
votesHelpful: I can see the path on the other side of it; there's even a treasure chest there! Just. . just please step over this tiny wall!!!" . . . . .It's not even a  hard puzzle to get around them

reviewText:
This game is the most frustrating pile of **** I have played in ages.

The control method and inventory system so annoying that the real battle I had was with that and not the zombies.

After an hour ****ing around with trying to get it started because the Windows validation software that comes packed in the game not working with Windows 8 and then having to create an account with them and then a few required updates I finally got to 'play'.

Dealing with the issues I had with the Windows account software was more fun than playing RE5. The controls hamper the game so much that it is just a frustrating chore. Unable to move whilst shooting?! What the funk? Confusing item management between you and your witless 'partner' during fights and a control system that doesn't work at all well either using mouse or controller.

I spent most of the hour I played this either watching cut scenes, fumbling around in the inventory pop up screen when under attack or listening to my character calmly voice over having a nice calm chat with some guy who was supposed to be sending in help wilst five zombies ripped at his face as I struggled to hit them (whilst stationary of course) with the melee weapon or swearing at the screen.

Wish I haddn't wasted my money on it.

reviewText:
I absolutely loved playing Resident Evil 4 on Gamecube so when I picked up this title at the STEAM sale I had some expecations. However, the series haven't really aged very well and despite playing with a controller, the game is just to clumsy and slow paced to be enjoyed when you are used to newer games.
Whne playing single player, all the flaws of RE becomes too hard to ignore. Bad acting, bad story, bad controls (even with controller) all adds up to that I don't enjoy. I tried to find the joy I once had playing RE4, but after a couple of hours it just wasn't there.

This was an awesome game when it was first released, but with today's gaming standards, I don't recommend it.

reviewText: So, I heard a lot of stories about this game and they weren't good ones. It's not Resident Evil anymore" they said. "Resident Evil 4 is better than this" they said. "Every Resident Evil after the 4th iteration is bad" they said. And what can I say? They're not right. It's as simple as that.\n\nAs harsh as this truth may be
date: Resident Evil has shifted its focus from classic survival horror to a more action oriented gameplay experience. But this already happened after Resident Evil 3: Nemesis. The fixed camera angles are missing in favor of a 3rd person perspective
recommended: the classic zombies from the first three games are no more and the story of the Umbrella corporation ended long before the setting of Resident Evil 4. So it shouldn't come as a surprise that Resident Evil 5
voteText: is more action oriented than the classic Resident Evil titles.\n\nIn fact
helpfulPercent: a lot of people liked Resident Evil 4
votesHelpful: but the fifth iteration wasn't all that well received. And I am asking myself: why is that? To me
votesTotal: Resident Evil 5 has numerous changes that made it better than it's predecessor. The controls on PC are marvelous compared to Resident Evil 4
votesFunny: the graphics are more advanced
commentsCount: some animations are nicer
column16: the mercenaries mode is better and it features some new enemies. But I also have to say that Resident Evil 5 plays a lot like Resident Evil 4.\n\nA lot of the animations are recycled or reused
column17: especially those for the Majini (which are basically reskinned Ganados from Resident Evil 4)
column18: it is still not possible to move whilst shooting and it just feels like Resident Evil 4
column19: the only real change being the setting in Africa (so you're fighting against black Ganados
column20: kind of) and the partner-mechanic
column21: allowing for co-op or a single player mode with benefits (or annoyances). Well
column23: too. Especially the inventory. It's gotten pretty small actually
column24: compared to the Resident Evil 4 inventory when maxed out. You got nine inventory slots in total which means that you can only afford to take 3 weapons with you at most
column25: I recommend carrying 2 weapons for each character so that you can still fit in first aid spray/herbs and grenades - or a bullet proof vest.\n\nAlso
column26: the merchant from Resident Evil 4 is gone
column27: that iconic figure. You will be missed. Aside from that
column28: the health bar system is different
column29: too. Instead of featuring a segmented bar which can be increased by consuming yellow herbs in combination with green herbs and red herbs
column30: you have a full bar with a set amount of health - rendering the yellow herb obsolete in the process
column31: which is why it was removed.\n\nBut aside from all this... Resident Evil 5 plays like Resident Evil 4 - just a little bit more simplified and with better looks. The puzzles
column34: boss battles and most of the animations are still the same. And what can I say? I liked Resident Evil 4 for what it was. The PC port was a horrible mess but I liked it nontheless. And so
column35: Resident Evil 5 is also a game I would call a "nice game". Not outstandingly great by any means. It's a 3rd person action shooting game in the Resident Evil universe.\n\nFans of the original games won't like Resident Evil 5 nor will they like Resident Evil 4 all that much. But if you don't give a damn about the "true Resident Evil experience" and just want to play a nice 3rd person shooter with mutants and zombies in it
column36: featuring some of your favourite characters from the Resident Evil universe and a bit of interesting lore
column37: I recommend this game to you. Is it worth the price? Maybe
column38: maybe not. But if it's on sale

reviewText:
A mediocre game but a lazy port job. Includes a decent amount of options, however horrible controls. Movement feels sluggish at times in comparison to previous Resident Evil games; It is especially worse when playing with a controller, although it doesn't seem to get much better when using a mouse and keyboard.

Aside from the port: The gameplay keeps you on edge. Enemies can approach you from ANY and ALL directions. There are various bosses you will encounter, and you will have several different, although similiar ways of getting past them. It can often become very challenging - even repetitive. You focus far too much on shooting your way out of almost every level, rather than considering a more 'tactical' approach as you may do so in previous games.

One of the better" things about Resident Evil 5 is the integration of CO-OP. I'll admit
date: it's a mess. Although players continue to suffer the many issues of multiplayer
recommended: it definitely seemed like a good idea from a player's standpoint - being able to play with friends can make the overall experience more enjoyable for some.\n\nMy final rating is a 6/10. Why do I recommend this game? Simply put
hoursPlayed: it is a game that you can waste a decent amount of time playing
voteText: even if you won't be missing out on much if you were to pass it up."

reviewText: As someone that absolutely despises Resident Evil 4 down to its core, I can honestly say that this is... a huge step forward, if not one of most enjoyable games in the series. Chris and Sheva are both strong, intelligent and competent, something braindead Leon and glorified damsel Ashley never will be. Infected Africa? Infinitely more interesting and aesthetically pleasing than the brown, bland smear that was Spain. The controls and gameplay are much more polished, fluid in their execution and despite the usual narm the series is known for, this plot is actually pretty damn interesting.\n\nIt may not be a traditional Resident Evil title by any means, but as a solid, influential action horror game? Resident Evil 5 delivers and then some, more so with the relatively recent removal of GWFL.

reviewText: I like this game, but the progress feels slow.  It is almost as though half of this game was made awesome and fun and the other half was made boring and slow.  I just wish I could skip the boring and slow levels.  This game would be much more fun if they did not use very old game mechanics.  In today's gaming, no one wants to see an animation of picking up gun bullets for the 30th time in 5 mins, should get it by being near it ect.  Almost the combat feels sluggish in an attempt to make you feel powerless, they could have counterd this with a built in hand to hand combat system alike Condemed Criminal Origins".  I enjoyed the coop very much but struggle with playing single player due to the feeling as though I was driving a tank instead of an agile man."

These are my favorite Apple Oatmeal bites

mix very very well.
form into balls and leave to set on parchment paper in the freezer for up to 4 hours

reviewText:

reviewText:
NOTE: Has finished the non-steam version before

The cutscenes and QTE-sessions in this game is purely epic, and did you know they were directed by a music-video director for Mariah Carey? His name is Jim Sonzero who later went on to direct the american remake of Pulse and the cutscenes in Killzone 3. Perfect cinematography, aggressive use of camera, powerful action! I had to award this game for that (Best Cutscenes). Other than that, the game's messy controls destroyed the gameplay experience for me. On mouse and keyboard, the camera was too sensetive and controls induced pain in my hands, on gamepad it got too slow and suicidal.

SCORE: 6,9/10
RESULT: I recommend Resident Evil 6 or Resident Evil Remake HD Remaster

reviewText:
I write this review (ALERT: i am playing RE5 since 2009) to late. But better late than never.
Just lazy i guess xD
PD: yes, i am a big fan / player from RE

The good:
- Good graphics for be a game from 2009. They're still amazing for me (more than RE6)
- Finally removed that anoying thing called Games For Windows Live"
- Gold Edition finally on PC!!!!
- Upgrade your weapons
date:
choose which weapon use in every mission.
- Many variety of enemies / mutations (some really deadly)
- Coop mode (i recomend that cause the AI is really bad / stupid in HIGH difficulties)
- Mercenaries Mode / No Mercy
- WESKER!!!

The Bad:
- Short story compared with RE4 or the old RE games (posible to finish in 2 hours "playing seriously")
- The AI is ridiculous. Sorry CAPCOM
recommended:
but i never saw so bad AI on my whole life

reviewText:
This game is a soulless co-op horror shooter featuring our old friends: Chris Redfield, Albert Wesker, Jill Valentine and a random african girl who I couldn't care less about. I can't put my finger on it, but something is very wrong with this whole game. Maybe the atmosphere, or the fact that there's too much action in it for a Resident Evil game.

The story of the game is actually a milestone in the series, but it lacks the epicness and the presentation is poor.  I mean come on, you can't be serious to kill Albert Wesker without Jill being a part in the actual fight, or any other main character whatsoever. Having a random new character doing half of the job... I'd rather take more cliche.
With this game Resident Evil offically turned into a guilty pleasure franchise of mine, but I still can't like this game. It has lost the spirit, and except the final boss there isn't anything memorable really, it's a big shame.

reviewText:
I am a huge fan of the Resident Evil series and have played every game (zero-4) to completion several times.  I was at the very least disappointed with most of this game.  The partner is shoe-horned in and her AI is broken.  Survival horror gives way to frustration when you realize that Sheva's stupid AI is what's getting you killed 9 out of 10 times.  If you can play co-op it might be enjoyable, but isn't this franchise supposed to give you a sense of lonely dread?  Co-op would destroy that feeling entirely.  Also, the 9-slot inventory similar to the original games seems like a step backward from the attaché case of RE4.  Throw in the racist bits in the swamp and this game can go ♥♥♥♥ itself.

There are some nice build up bits in the beginning similar to the village from RE4, but where that game took it's time before going nuts, this game just throws you into a bunch of plagas infected villagers the first chance it gets.  Even the guns feel less responsive.  Everything is just a step backwards from the masterpiece of RE4.  I bought this game since I own all the franchise and I wanted the collection to be complete, but I never thought when purchasing that I could hate a Resident Evil game this much.  I think I actually prefer 6 to this.
2/10

reviewText:
Bought this as part of a Humble Bundle. As such, this purchase only respresented pennies, so no harm done.

I didn't enjoy what I saw of the gameplay, but if you're a series fan then the strange tankiness of the movement and being forced to stand still to shoot are fine for you and you may well love the game.

However, even if I'd liked the gameplay, the graphics break down into the characteristic diagonal screen-splintering of a dying graphics card. My graphics card is fine, though; it's a 4GB NVidia card, which happily plays most games at 1440p. In a way, I can be thankful the game is unenjoyable to me or this would be frustrating.

reviewText:
We now live in a world where the original, GFWL version of a game is superior to its newer Steamworks iteration. What the hell, Capcom.

This version's .exe still redirects to GFWL's servers, so you're going to have to install all that crap again. Afterwards, an unsightly launcher will still be present on your desktop, displaying errors, but its okay, because the game will boot up. But prior to this, I had to drop a .dll file into my install directory or the GFWL installation would crap out? What even? They've also gutted DX10 support in this one and apparently Versus mode or split screen co-op is also borked?

Add to the fact that the game still costs $20 vanilla, or $30 with DLC, 5+ years after release. I paid ~$2 CDN in a bundle for this so whatever, plus the game underneath is still pretty decent.

It's like a way, way less charming and way, way less tightly refined version of RE4. Instead of Ashley being unobtrusive and super annoying, you have sassy not-Ada being a mule for your gear. Instead of Leon's glorious bishie sparkles, you have Chris punching boulders. Instead of being in not-Spain, you're in some place called Kijiji fighting the Ebola Corporation or whatever.

Steep sale only or get it on PS3/360 instead.

reviewText:
Rank: 3/10
Recommendation(s): Don't play this game.
Major Theme: Who was smoking what, when?
Bought at Price: $8.81 (Humble Bundle $0.98/game)

This game from the controls, to the graphics, to Games for Windows Life.. Just isn't right.

I patched the game to remove the need for GFWL, which for some reason is still required to port saves according to the developers. After that, I discovered that the controls are some of the worse of I've used. Sensitivity changes on the fly (who knows why), the FoV is like taping the screen to your face, and control layout with a keyboard and mouse is worse than Call of Duty Black Ops. Add on top that you stop moving when you aim, I'm just happy to know that I gave all my money to Humble and Charity.

You will only buy this game for the love of the series, or you seriously like console ports.

The best part about the game was when I uninstalled it. You will find that the calling part is the 2nd most enjoyable part when you get to annoy your partner.

reviewText:
Capcom really doesn't support this game.  You'll want to download some of maluc's patches for . . . various things. (Note:  A comment on this review stated maluc patches break the game for Windows XP.  So be awarre, and if you have Windows XP maybe don't use maluc patches)  There are bugs in this port, like teleporting doors in multiplayer (breaks your game in amazing ways you wouldn't even think possible), essential enemy in 6-3 not appearing to drop an essential keycard (there is a workaround but only if you're pretty well versed) &c &c &c

The game itself is pretty nice, looks OK in my opinion, plays decently.  If you really really like the game you can overlook a lot of the faults . . . sort of.  But then, if you feel that strongly this negative review will not dissuade you.

For anyone that's on the fence - well, it's true a lot of companies don't give proper support to ports.  But if you think you're going to be able to fix a problem if you do have one from official support, better think again.

Personally I really liked the game for its gameplay.  But just because I personally like the game and continue to play it doesn't mean I can quite in good conscience recommend a middling port that has some serious flaws.

reviewText: Hmm, I have mixed feelings with this one. Why ? Well, it misses the horror from previous RE games and it seems more action oriented. Yes, that IS a shame. Don't get me wrong, it's not a bad game by any means; it looks superb and it plays great as well. It's just that there are (almost) no scary parts anymore. Blame the enemies, the co-op or even the sunlit enviroments, I don't know what it is. But it makes me kinda sad. I just hope RE6 will be about the horror again. Anyway, if you're looking for a solid third person shooter, or if you're just a big RE fan (not that big I guess, or you would've owned it already), grab this one.\n\n[Rating: 80/100]

reviewText:
While I would recommend Resident Evil 4 for its interesting, survival enough, first half, I'm definitely not going to recommend this one.
It is fun to play in coop with a friend, sure, but that's also one of the reasons why it COMPLETELY lost its survival horror nature.
Your first concern won't be surving, it will be slaughtering as many monsters as you can see. This is where the series became a third person action shooter (oh and now the monsters also shoots you back with firearms, in case it wasn't an action shooter enough)...
Characters are absolutely the worst:
- how they transformed Chris (in the end he also SMASH a giant volcano rock with his fists)
- how they transformed Jill
- how the whole Wesker thing ends... really irrespectful of how big of an antagonist he was
- Sheva, the big booby woman I can't even remember the name of and the others...

You want to play this with a friend so you can just have fun regardless of what game are you playing? (they could have called this game African Crazy Shooter 5 and none would have found similitaries to Resident Evil)
Buy it then and have fun, you're going to share a few laughs with your buddies.

BUT if...
You want to play this game because you loved Resident Evil and just want more of its story and survival gameplay?
STAY AWAY FOR YOUR OWN SAKE... this game takes the WORST part of Resident Evil 4, get it even worse and make a whole game out of it.

reviewText:
Resident Evil/Biohazard has been a beloved zombie shooter for many years now. However, despite the praise of its atmosphere and gameplay, the game was regularly criticized for its clunky movement controls and unintuitive U.I. Resident Evil needed to evolve and rework these dated issues if it wanted to survive its own longetivity. In 2005, RE4 hit the market with overwhelming positive reviews. It pioneered the over the shoulder view of shooters, delivering superb gameplay, action, and smooth UI/controls. The community's only issue was they wanted to play the thriller with a friend. Capcom heard the plight and RE5 was announced. We were all ready to pounce on the idea that we could finally RE in co-op....however, we learned the hard way that we might have jumped the shark, as well as received another punishing lesson on Why we don't pre-order games."

Plot 4/10

In typical RE fasion
voteText: and told from the perspective of a 10 yr old that was along for the ride. reviewText:
KICK-♥♥♥ GAME, DESPITE A GOD-AWFUL SAVE MODE
9.5/10

Third person shooter set in Africa (the first part looks like Somalia/Black Hawk Down, the second like Temple of Doom/King Solomon's mines + a secret bioterrist lab);  a solid game full of action, scares, stress, puzzles, a hot female partner, awesome graphics, no bugs, and a story full of twists which meets all loose ends of the RE franchise (yes, Wesker APPEARS here...)
My only complain is that you can't move while aiming/reloading, but other than that the gameplay is solid, and the game works like a charm with the highest settings  for 2010 (and beyond) computers, no problems with Win 8 either

If you loved RE4 you'll love 5, simple as that, this game is the DIRECT sequel of RE4, very, VERY similar games; the RE franchise may not be Survival Horror anymore, more like a kick-♥♥♥ Survival Shooter revamped franchise; anyway, you'll be scared, oh yes, by facing a horde of infected zulu warriors hell bent on killing you...with only 4 bullets left...

Overall this game is the most realistic RE yet: by using a reduced inventory (only 9 items!, and that includes the medicines and ammo), it's clear that the developers want you to make decisions: more ammo or more meds? should I carry just the shotgun and bazooka? will I survive without the always reliable hand gun? will I find enough shotgun ammo? should I sacrifice the vest since I usually kill the enemies from a distance? etc etc. DECISIONS, MAN! DECISIONS!

And there's the ONE BIG FLAW of this game: lack of manual save...
Anyway, you can always load a saved game to collect more ammo/gold since they respawn EVERY time you just reload an autosaved game (NOTE!: the game only saves on auto, you can't manually save, AND the checkpoints DON'T reload if you quit the game; keep that in mind to avoid frustration, unless you're a noob, you should know by now that A CHECKPOINT ISN'T ALWAYS AN AUTOSAVE FILE)
ANOTHER TIP: every time you quit, the game will ASK you if you wanna SAVE THE INVENTORY-> keep in mind that CHOOSING YES will save your current ammo/gold, and that CAN be a problem: for example, I reloaded a saved game with tons of ammo, but a boss kicked my ♥♥♥; tired of dying-reloading-dying-reloading-dying-etc, I called t quits for the day, then I chose yes-save the inventory" option without realizing what the hell  I was doing (I was sleepy)
date: and the result was that the game saved my inventory with almost NO BULLETS left; I nearly had a seizure...for real; in other words
recommended: YOU SHOULD ONLY SAVE YOUR INVENTORY AFTER ADVANCING A CHAPTER OR AFTER DEFEATING A BOSS
hoursPlayed: BUT NEVER AFTER GETTING KILLED...\n\nIgnore the bitter hipster haters that still think this franchise should have ended after RE3
voteText: the RE franchise is alive and well (check out my review of RE6
helpfulPercent: that game didn't suck at all...)\n\nPD: you'll find a lot of noobs crying here because the game cannot work without GFWL; well
votesHelpful: it's not that difficult to just SHUT DOWN the damn thing
votesTotal: bunch of noobs..."

reviewText: When Resident Evil 5 was released back then, I was not really interested in the game as there were some reviews that state the game is rather, going backwards compared to Resident Evil 4. So, I have been avoiding it for a while and now I finally gave it a chance and well, guess what, I think this game is definitely one of the best games I have ever played. Good story is there, I like the fact that there is a partner that follows you. But unfortunately, I think there are some issues with the control. It can be hard to change weapons or use items as you can not just pause the game and do what you need to do without getting attacked. Yes, changing weapons and using items and such all happen in real time, so you better get used to it. And sometimes the AI of the partner can be dumb and annoying, and I really don't think all the weapon change and item use should be this inconvenient. But despite the fact that there are some visible flaws, with awkward control, actually that kind of adds fear onto the player even more, and I would say that is a good thing. Overall, great game.\n\n9.1 out of 10.

I didn't play this game so much, but when I played, I liked it.
This game is very boring when you're playing alone, you need someone to play with you. (Unfortunately, I don't have someone to play with, but I won't stop play it)
I expected for more from this game, but I'm disappointed.
The combat system is O.K, the AI is O.K too, the graphics...well...impressive, and the sounds are great.
I don't know the plot, so I can't tell you.
Well...this game is O.K, not something to be proud of, but it's O.K.
Oh, one more thing, this game isn't scary, I expected from it to be scary, but it isn't.
I'll give it 6\10.

reviewText:
Like Resident evil 1-3 ? You won't like this game.
Instead, did you like RE4? In this case, you will enjoy this game.
Forget Horror survival. Sure, there are scary moments. But this a 3rd person zombie shooter. No Nemesis running against you, no running around in a mansion grabing a key and running again. No sir, this game is straighfoward to the action.
Like shooter games with a twist and a good variety of enemys? That's is a game for you. If instead you are hardcore RE fan, then this is not a RE game.
Also co-op makes this game 200% better. So many laughs. Play it with a friend and you're guarateed to have fun.

reviewText:
This is my second favourite RE game, after Resident Evil 4.  The gameplay is similar although I prefer RE4's inventory system - it is more simplified in RE5, also the game does not pause when you bring it up to switch items which can lead to frustration during hectic gameplay.

Graphically the game is excellent and it still looks very good even for 2015 imo.  It also runs very smoothly and is a high quality port.  Music and voice acting are also excellent.

The main campaign is a lot shorter than RE4's, my fastest playthrough was 3hrs 9mins (on a successive playthrough with upgraded weapons etc.).  If you play normally and don't rush it might take you about twice that long.  There is plenty of incentive to play through the campaign multiple times, to get all the Steam achievements, find all the treasure, buy and upgrade all the weapons and get enough points to unlock all the bonus unlockable items, figurines, additional characters etc.

The game has a great atmosphere, the action is very satisfying and the characters are likeable and you enjoy their company.  On the negative side, your partner's AI is poor at times and they often get themselves killed (because they don't defend themselves for example), don't heal you quickly enough so you die, or walk in front of you while you are trying to shoot.  On the higher difficulty levels this can be infuriating.  I have completed the game on Professional difficulty which was EXTREMELY frustrating at times - but it can be done.

The DLC is short but good fun (especially Lost in Nightmares) as is the additional Mercenaries mode with new characters.

Now that the game has Steam cloud support and has ditched the hated GFWL I highly recommend it.

reviewText: I knew what I was getting into. Awful controls, horrible camera angles, cheese story... and yet I finished it. I really don't know why, maybe because I wanted to test the most powerful weapons, maybe because my attachment with the previous installments of the series, maybe because I found the final bosses quite cool and challenging... but It's impossible for me to recommed this game, everything is outdated, the controls are so horrid than to compensate them you have stupid ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ enemies who takes ages to react to your presence, you will spend more time fighting against the controls that being inmersed in the game fighting the enemies... yes, I know it's RE style and it's a 2009 game, but the genre has evolved a lot since then and frankly there is no place for a game where you feel more frustated for the controls and gameplay than thrilled for it.

El juego no es una obra de arte, no es survival horror, no tiene sustos y tampoco tiene tantas armas y/o enemigos como otros resident evil. Esto significa que este sea un mal juego? En absoluto.

El juego es largo, divetido de jugar y aunque la trama no sea un bombazo, yo creo que se pueden pasar unas saludales 20h jugandolo. Lo recomiendo mucho si dispones del dinero.

reviewText:
It says I played this game for three hours, but it feels like many many more as it  is one of the most tedious games I played recently. Imagine narrow corridors disguised as alleys, narrow corridors disguised as hallways, narrow corridors disguised as sewers, narrow corridors disguised as pathways between containers and you get the idea.  Eventually we will get to narrow corridors disguised as narrow corridors.
At heart most games are basically linear in concept, but this one is so obviously confined to just one narrow path that it's sucks the fun out of the game and what is more, there is virtual no story, no atmosphere , no interesting characters and no interesting dialogue to keep you going.
The gameplay itself contributes to this monotonous tedium. You spent half the time scavenging for ammo which you find in small portions but need in large amounts because all the adversaries take multiple hits in the head alone.. shooting other area's of the body just make them blink or fall down for a moment, if you are lucky. And the game throws lots of them at you.
Combat itself is an awkward affair. Nothing seems to work quite right. It is almost comical how the ai works.. with enemies lumbering towards you and staring past you while making threatening movements away from you. Combat is sluggish.
Personally I couldn't fathom why you would want to play this game when there are some many better ones out there.
If you like a game with a good story, captivating atmosphere and interesting characters, try Resident Evil Revelations 2.
If, on the other hand, you like shooters, look elsewhere as well. Give Spec Ops: The Line a try.  The combat is a lot better.
If you like a tedious monotonous linear game that you only play because you are a RE fan and you  are charmed by the hot side kick Sheva then buy RE 5.  But only when it's on sale.. for paying more than a few bucks for being bored is a waste of your money and your life.
Anyway.. if you still want to give RE 5 a try I hope you have fun.

reviewText:
RE5 is pretty good. It isn't scary, but neither was RE4 and that was pretty good too.
Be sure to:
1. Never carry the same weapon types as your partner
[this removes arguments of ammo and the AI will gift ammo to you]
2. Always let an AI partner have the rifle
[the AI never misses a head shot and is lightning fast]
3. don't be a puss, play on veteran first, and always go for X button finishers

Mercs mode is what the solo game should have been.
Desperate escape is brief, but a nice challenge.
Lost in Nightmares is brief and embarrassingly bad.
Vs mode is just odd and you'll wonder how they thought a competitive-stand-in-place shooter could possibly work.

Overall, a very pretty, fun game worth about 15 dollars.

reviewText:
Ah. Resident Evil 5. A game that to this date seems to suffer from the love-it-or-hate-it syndrome.
Too bad for it, RE5 was a follow up to Capcom's most excellent (and to this day one of the best games ever made) Resident Evil 4. Let's start with a simple question: Is it as good as RE4? Hell no. But that poses another, possibly more important inquiry: Is it a good game? Hell yes.

RE5 on its own is a solid, pretty (despite the gray-ish color palette) and fun experience. For its age it still holds up surprisingly well, it runs at constant 60fps even during cutscenes (which sometimes seems not to be intended causing some graphical issues) and its replay value is actually quite high. Even more so than RE4's.
As far as gameplay goes it's more of the same if you played RE4. Run around, aim, shoot, explore, hit some bad guys, solve some incredibly simple puzzles (except for one particular one that actually makes you think a little bit), break boxes with your knife, get hit by a snake and run some more. Oh, and the ocassional boss fight here and there. It even adds up to the already solid gameplay with more contect-sensitive actions, like melee strings with your partner (Oh yeah, this game has an active partner) which can be very useful.
Its main attractive of course is co-op, which drastically improves both the experience and replay value. Online co-op works well but as always playing with people you know is the best choice, as items, ammo and weapons are shared and that can get a bit complex when playing with randoms.
Speaking of weapons and replay value, another great point for the game is its upgrading system. After you -or your partner- get a weapon you can buy it from the store, so no worries if  you missed it. Upgrading your weapons is a very effective tool to survive longer, though it costs money. You can then use those weapons on previous episodes and make your life easier, or your partner's if you are playing with a newcomer or wanna get stuff you missed. Let me tell you, replaying the first chapter is a whole different experience with an upgraded arsenal and some serious firepower.

Overall this game benefits greatly from co-op and I'd dare say it makes it an actually unique experience, at least for its time. If you're one of those who skipped it because it wasn't RE4-2 or forced the co-op on you, give it a chance, I know I did and I don't regret it.

reviewText:
This is my second favourite RE game, after Resident Evil 4.  The gameplay is similar although I prefer RE4's inventory system - it is more simplified in RE5, also the game does not pause when you bring it up to switch items which can lead to frustration during hectic gameplay.

Graphically the game is excellent and it still looks very good even for 2015 imo.  It also runs very smoothly and is a high quality port.  Music and voice acting are also excellent.

The main campaign is a lot shorter than RE4's, my fastest playthrough was 3hrs 9mins (on a successive playthrough with upgraded weapons etc.).  If you play normally and don't rush it might take you about twice that long.  There is plenty of incentive to play through the campaign multiple times, to get all the Steam achievements, find all the treasure, buy and upgrade all the weapons and get enough points to unlock all the bonus unlockable items, figurines, additional characters etc.

The game has a great atmosphere, the action is very satisfying and the characters are likeable and you enjoy their company.  On the negative side, your partner's AI is poor at times and they often get themselves killed (because they don't defend themselves for example), don't heal you quickly enough so you die, or walk in front of you while you are trying to shoot.  On the higher difficulty levels this can be infuriating.  I have completed the game on Professional difficulty which was EXTREMELY frustrating at times - but it can be done.

The DLC is short but good fun (especially Lost in Nightmares) as is the additional Mercenaries mode with new characters.

Now that the game has Steam cloud support and has ditched the hated GFWL I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
Resident Evil 5 is one of the most amazing games of all time. The story sets of with Chris Redfield and his new partner Sheva Alomar trying to stop biological weapons spreading in Africa. The story has a big twist from Chapter 4 and on. It becomes totally different which is a very welcoming thing. Resident Evil 5's graphics are simply stunning for a game that came out in 2009. Character models are great and so is the sound + voice acting. There is extreme fun to be had in Resident Evil 5 alone or with a friend/relative. This is definitely the best 3RD person Survival Horror" game I've ever played.
Graphics: 10/10
Story: 9.5/10
Sound : 9.5/10
Multiplayer/Co-op: 10/10
Overall: 9.7/10
Resident Evil 5 is without a doubt one of my favorite games of all times. Not does it only do all thing's correct but it expands survival horror in a new genre of co-op fun.
I finished this game 11 times and counting. It never gets old and there is a MASSIVE replay ability to be found. Incredible Game."

reviewText:
The longer I play this game, the more I like it ;-)

First let me summarize,
graphics: 8/10
physics: 2/10
sound: 6/10
dialogues: 2/10
gameplay: 8/10
overall (considering fun, challenge and so on): 8/10


THE GOOD THINGS:

- Theres good interaction between the partner player and you. I mean the coop does not stand in  your way. The coop kills enemies like you, sometimes successfully and sometimes not.

- Unlimited and configurable framerate. Smooth gameplay is possible.

- Many opportunities to act tactically: Before beginning new levels, the player can buy weapons, add them to the inventory or equip the character

- You can skip many cutscenes, no need to wait.

- Challenging gameplay

- Nice, realistic animations of the enemies. Different target zones of the enemies. Vulnerable and protected parts of the animated characters.


THE BAD THINGS:

- No decent physics effects

I like action games with decent physics effects. Unfortunately there's almost no physics and no ragdoll effects.

- Annoying dialogues

The most annoying thing is the conversation part between the two characters. For example:
If your partner helps you (shiva) she always asks are you okay?" or "you have to be careful"
You have to be careful - how silly is this???
It would have been better if there had been an option to turn this off.

- Some bad animations and items

If you kill a zombie he does not fall to the ground and bleed.
No. Insted he falls to the ground and - after a few seconds - some bubbles occur and the corpse vanishes.
I thought this would be a game for people over 18 and that it would contain some action and violence - I was wrong.

If you kill an enemy the corpse vanishes and either there occurs some gold coins
date:
ammonition or a plant.
A plant???? Yes a plant!!! You use plants to heal you or your partner.
But when you pick up the plant - it occurs as a laboratory test tube in your inventory.
And if you use this tube you handle it as a spray. The animation is like you use a hair spray.
THIS is not logical. It's ridiculous.

Another silly animation: If your partner helps you
recommended: he or she stabs some kind of needle into your stomach. The player has protective clothes but it is possible to apply some kind of syringe. hm...\n\nIf you shoot an enemy in the head and don't get a clear headshot
hoursPlayed:
the enemy pivots the head. This seems to be scriped animation. In the 90s it was ok to show such animations - but today these predictable animations have been replaced by good physics. Not in this game ;-(
Ok there is also some physics - for example the impact of explosive things like grenades.
And on the other hand it is a challenge to aim at the.... *g*





Some info (not bad critics
voteText:
but info)

Particularities of the GAME CONTROLS:

The first things that I noticed when I started playing were the controls. Or better: The realisation of the way you can move your character. It's not comparable with the controls in common ego shooter. For a 3rd person shooter it's ok.

I can't look at a right angle to the ground or to the sky. Theres only a specific angle possible.
I cant jump whenever I want. I only can jump if theres a possibilty.
If I walk I can strafe. But if I run I can't.
If the player does not walk he can turn quickly by moving the mouse.
But if he moves he only can turn the character slowly.

Aiming:
The character can't aim steadily. Instead the crosshair swings slowly around the target.
I assume they wanted to simulate real aiming
helpfulPercent: considering that a human can't keep the hands still while breathing.\nNice idea
votesHelpful: why not ;-) So it's more important to pull the trigger in the right moment when shooting."

reviewText:
Definitely not as bad as people make it seem. Doesn't have the same tone that Resident Evil 4 had (at least the first half of that game had a tight vibe) but I enjoyed it and it's goofy boss fights.
Seems to have borrowed substantially from Gears of War but honestly I only have two huge gripes

1) was having to manage Sheva and her awful AI while trying not to let Chris get his face eaten. It was worse than baby sitting Ashley in RE4 because Sheva can fend for herself but she's an idiot.

2) The last boss was frustrating because I kept running out of ammo and had no way of beating it. I read some things online that said to farm gold/treasure, upgrade, get ammo but honestly even when being conservative I seemed to run out. I enabled infinite ammo to beat it, which is scummy I know, but i was at the point i just wanted to finish the game and get it over with. Never had an issue with ammo until then though, seemed to be in abundance and then the final boss takes so much punishment before he dies that no amount of ammo i could store in my inventory was a enough.
